I was excited to play this game on release, but something about it isn't very fun at all.

The main gameplay of playing and discarding hands isn't exactly riveting as it just devolves into playing same one hand you're optimizing for. The shopping and "decision making" is another bummer where you either get the good jokers or you're scraping by with random assortment of hardly useful bunch that you can't do anything with. Once you're past the 2nd ante it becomes impractical to pivot your build and you end up limping till the finish line or getting shafted by luck somewhere along the line and then your run just ends.

I doesn't feel like if I win or if I lose is decided by me in any real part - game just plays for itself. Meh.

Extremely based game. I absolutely despise roguelikes, but love this one.
It has a few tricks as to why I enjoy it.
1. There's no story or pressure to actually win runs beyond unlocking more stuff.
2. The random generation actually makes for immense replayability in this one, as it's not about mastering any kind of layouts or mechanics. Even cards you've seen a million times can have completely different meanings in new constellations.
3. The game gives you the seed to your run when you win or lose, allowing you to replay or share it.

The aesthetic and art style are also awesome, as are the card designs.

As of this writing, 98% of the reviews for this game are positive here on Steam. It's not that this game will appeal to everyone, but rather that just about anyone who thought they might like it definitely did. What does that mean for you? It simply means that if you think the screenshots look interesting, then you'll almost certainly like it.

The game is pretty straight-forward. A single play-through is all it takes to figure out all of the basic mechanics. You draw a hand of playing cards, discard and redraw up to a set number of times, and try to make the best poker hands. Better hands earn more points and you want as many of those as possible. Once you earn the threshold amount of points, you get to move on with a few dollars added to your pocket.

In between each set of hands, you get to visit a shop where you can buy things with the money you've earned. Some of the things to buy include Joker Cards (which tweak the rules for the run while sitting outside your deck), Tarot Cards (which are single-use abilities, most of which modify individual cards in some way), Celestial Cards (which improve the scores of individual hands you might play), Regular Cards (which you add to the basic 52 card deck), or Tickets (which are kind of like Jokers, but don't take up one of the limited Joker spots). You can also sell off Jokers that you aren't using anymore when you're ready to pivot your strategy.

There are a ton of different cards in each of the categories and getting further (or earning achievements) unlocks new ones that will start randomly spawning in the pool every time the shop refreshes.

I saw someone else on here complaining that the game required a ton of math. That is very false. You certainly could try to work out the exact number of points that any particular play would earn you (factoring in all of the modifiers that are about to affect your score), but that level of detail and foresight is simply unnecessary. Almost always, the highest scoring play that's available to you at any moment is fairly obvious. In the rare case that it isn't obvious, it's usually because a couple of different plays will score similarly. Either way, it's normally pretty safe to act without a whole lot of anxiety or analysis. Stress in this game doesn't come from a pressure to do math, but rather the constant testing of your tolerance for risk. Should you take the Joker that gives you more points or the one that gives you more money? More money might be better in the long run, but that won't matter if you can't earn enough points to survive until you get to the next shop. These are the hard decisions.

The game is very well done for what it is. I can't think of too many ways that it could be improved. As I said in the beginning, if it looks to you like you might like it, then you almost certainly will. I have no reservations about giving it a firm recommendation to anyone who's even a bit curious. Worth it at full price.
I just cant't stop playing

I'm having some fun with Balatro, but it's also leaving me unsatisfied.

Poker is both the game's strength and its weakness.

It's a strength because anyone with even a passing familiarity with Poker will have no problem getting into the flow, and its simplicity makes for a low effort casual experience.

It's a weakness because you're bound by the conventions of Poker, however overlaying Balatro's game mechanics on top breaks some fundamental parts of that game. For example, with Poker you'd mostly be happy with a high pair of face cards, whereas Balatro has you pulling flushes on the first roll and thereby immediately devaluing that as an achievement. If you ever have to play down a single pair in this game you may as well just about concede your entire run at that point. Seriously.

This gives the game nowhere to go for those big pay off moments, like laying a full house of 2s and 3s over the top of a couple of pairs of aces and queens. Instead, Balatro is mostly about just watching your score get bigger and bigger.

On a similar note, the odds and associated payoffs are flawed because they're based on Poker odds, they're not adjusted for this game's quirks. For example, Balatro has both much larger hand sizes and also much more capacity for draw. This strongly favours flushes, which are generously rewarded, over pairs/triples/four of a kind because there's 13 of each suit and only 4 of each rank.

The game also lacks any type of theme other than some quirky joker pictures, you're just watching hearts and clubs. (One might argue that this is inevitable when you're stuck with a standard 52 card deck, but there are many solitaire variants that make theming work really well.)

Balatro trades Poker's push your luck tension and simplicity for something that is ultimately less interesting, that is, ride the wave of higher and higher scores until the game breaks your strat by changing the rules on you without notice - which should be a cardinal sin in a game that only allows you to make tiny incremental tweaks along the way, and that absolutely does not reward flexible deck building.

Balatro isn't badly done, and it's got the usual addictive qualities of slot machines and other gambling-based games, but it's only a soft recommendation from me. Something significant has been missed in trading the satisfaction of laying down an amazing hand against the odds for something that is ultimately much less interesting - tweaking your score multipliers over multiple rounds while you play essentially the same hand, round after round, until either the game breaks you or you break the game.

A few reasons I like it more than StS (which is in my top 10 games ever) is that it plays at a much quicker pace, feels less brutally punishing and is more visually and sonically appealing to me. Please don't take this as a dump on StS because I love that game to death and that should tell you how freakishly good Balatro is. One of the best roguelikes I played, up there with StS and Hades.

Balatro is an amazing roguelike that solves a lot of issues with the genre that many other games struggle with. These issues are:

- [b] Unlear effects and numbers  [/b]
     This refers to the problem in many rougelikes where you get an item and it says something like "Improves attack damage when an enemy is frozen" or in some cases just says some flavor text like "toxic". This tells the player nothing about what the item or whatever does and it makes it very difficult to get into, many times requiring wikis open or other such things. In many cases, even when the stats and effects are clear, it can be very difficult to figure out how good it is before you pick it up, and sometimes even after you pick it up. This makes it take quite a while to really get into a rougelike because there is so much knowledge you have to learn to know what items are good and which suck.
     Balatro solves this by having each card description being relatively simple and very clear. It helps that the base of the game is simple too. The scoring system is also pretty simple to understand, to the point where you can calculate things on your own if you so choose (which I have done on a few occasions - its fun). When you play a hand, you clearly see how each joker effects your score and how they effect each other. This helps you get into the game quickly by very clearly showing you what each and every item does

- [b] Poor balance [/b]
     This is something thats hard to do, so I understand it, but many rougelikes suffer from it. What I mean by "poor balance" more specifically here is a decent amount of items that are either insanely run-winningly good and/or items that sound neat but end up being complete and udder trash. This creates runs where you get wins that you didn't really work for along with runs where you try to commit to a certain strategy or build that ends up sucking because the balance is off. This ties into the point above but it gets worse when something is really bad but it isn't obvious how bad it is. 
     Balatro isn't perfect about balance, but it feels a lot better than other rougelikes I've played. I've not encountered a joker that has been so good it won my run on its own, and I also haven't encountered any jokers that are uselessly bad, and even if they are, the game makes it pretty clear that its gonna suck. Even so, they usually work in some build somewhere, or have a niche during a certain point in a run which makes them useful. 

- [b] Obscure build knowledge [/b]
     This one is a real big problem with rougelikes. Many rougelikes out there are very very unclear about what builds you can go for and if they are even worth your time at all. The items may give some impressions here and there, but many times it will be difficult to tell if its worth it to commit to. There is also the case in some games where certain mechanics or calculations that are INCREDIBLY obtuse and unclear to the player are INSANELY important to the game and creating good builds. It also hurts when games try to make a bunch of items for certain types of builds, but those builds are god awful because they don't work within the game very well.
     Again, Balatro solves this with incredibly clear synergy and calculation. As I said above, you can calculate what is going to happen yourself so when you are thinking if a certain card is worth it or not, you can do the math to figure it out. Not many other games have that ability. The way the game is played, again, is also very simple which makes builds pretty easy to figure out. I've found a lot of success and fun in this game by buying a decent joker early on and trying to commit hard to building around it, and it works!

- [b] Crazy skill checks [/b]
     This could be considered a good thing I guess, but I tend to have issue with it. What I mean is when a rougelike throws a boss at you that you've never seen before and you die very quickly. Then, in order to fight it again you have to play a whole new run, get to that point, die, and then try again. It makes it really hard to learn patterns and learn how to fight the bosses, especially when they are late game or don't always appear.
     Balatro solves this by not really having much player skill involved. Most of Balatro is figuring out which build would be the best, making tricky decisions, and hedging your bets. The "skill" in balatro is knowing when to discard and what to discard to achieve which hand. Everything else is trying to figure out which item or card or whatever will help your build the most. It's also a chill game without any urgency which means you can take your time and think a lot if you so please. 


To be fair to other rougelikes, many games solve some of these problems on their own, and I'm sure there are games other than Balatro that don't have any of these issues. My main point, really, is that Balatro gets you to the "end game" of a rougelike much quicker than others do. By "end game" I mean when you get a lot of knowledge and experience in a game and know what you want to do and what decisions to make and what is good. 

Essentially Balatro is good and a ton of fun if you love to strategize and think about numbers. I love it.

A grind against RNG.

Good for gambling addicts looking to save money. Bad for deckbuilding players who don't want burnout from RNG-rot.

Art-style is fun, love the joker card aesthetics and the creativity to find so many variations. However, the sheer volume of variation reeks of 'what else can we come up with to get to 150' rather than a statistically-supported collection of Joker cards that encourage the player to find synergies. Instead, I feel very discouraged because of constantly poor RNG while drawing from bloated decks and bloated perk pools filled with meh perks that rarely connect together. Even if they do, 'bosses' can still be OP, especially since there's little to no time to change how your deck and jokers might play in order to compensate for a boss's negative effect.

Maybe the roguelike roll-out of more powerful perks is too slow.
But where I'm at in the game, with plenty of perks unlocked, the feeling is overwhelming that this is a grind against RNG.

8 hours in and still two 'Antes' away from ever winning.

Now THIS is a suitable substitute for my current gambling addiction.

I am now 10 hours in and haven't lost my entire savings yet.

Thank you.

I've played video poker a few times in Vegas, free drinks and what not, though I was never really that into it. This is my new addiction now. If you like poker, get this game; if you like poker and card builders, perhaps don't get this game, because you won't be able to stop playing.

My first impressions of Balatro were really positive! I'm a fan of roguelike card games (I've enjoyed MTG drafting for over a decade now), and the art and aesthetic of this game are gorgeous. I've played daily since release! And in fact, for the first 30 or so hours, I think Balatro is a joy to play, and I'd highly recommend it.

However, the more I play, the shallower the gameplay loop feels. Without spoiling too much, there's more-or-less an "optimal" strategy for maximizing hand points, and once you figure it out, most runs follow the same "arc" -- you look for the same types of cards in the early game, the mid game, and the late game. ([spoiler]Hafu figured out Hack + Glass + Red Seal in the invitational tournament, and I was really hoping there would be more depth to the late late game than that, but sadly X multipliers + retriggers really do rule the roost when it comes to exponential hand growth. You just can't progress past Ante 12 without abandoning pretty much all +Chips/+Mult-type modifiers.[/spoiler])

There are a few really cool combos, where cards synergize super well together and feel awesome when they work (such as [spoiler]Midas Mask + Pareidolia + Vampire[/spoiler]), but these kinds of interactions are relatively rare. I found that far more often I'd encounter antisynergistic "nonbos" or completely useless/dead cards, leading to frustration as I reroll and pray that I get one of the 5-10 cards that would actually elevate a given run to "viable" status.

The developers do try to add novelty to the game (through challenges, alternate decks, boss blinds, and rare occurrences). But, I find that it's still not enough to break free from the core limitations of the engine (A 52 card playing pool, with only + and x being the main score modifiers). After a while, it starts to feel more like "numbers go up" and nothing more.

My main suggestion to the devs would be to minimize the amount of "dead weight" common jokers (there's a lot of redundancy!!), and add new jokers that foster neat interactions. Also, perhaps add additional jokers that balance the lower tier hands? [spoiler]Almost all of my wins revolve around flush-based decks, with some straights and full houses mixed in. By comparison, there's very little reward for pursuing a high card/pair/two pair build.[/spoiler] I would be playing much more if I didn't have to slog through the boring jokers just to find the small subset of jokers that create a meaningful, interesting run. 

(I'll be keeping an eye out for future updates, though, and I'll happily revise my review if it turns out that the game has more replayability than v1.0.0 does! There's so so so much promise here.)

Balatro: A Roguelike Poker Masterpiece

In the realm of gaming, there exists a term that transcends mere entertainment; it's a concept so profound that it demands attention. Enter "Balatro"  a name whispered among the elite, a game that defies conventional labels and redefines what it means to be truly engrossed in the art of play.

Derived from the Latin word meaning "a jester" or "a buffoon," Balatro is anything but foolish. It's a symphony of strategy and chance, elegantly orchestrated within the confines of a digital deckbuilder. But to reduce Balatro to a mere deckbuilder is to miss the point entirely  it is an experience that transcends genres, a hypnotic journey into the heart of illegal poker hands and adrenaline-fueled gambits.

At its core, Balatro is a roguelike adventure where every hand is a gamble and every decision holds weight. The allure of forbidden poker games beckons, drawing players into a world where discovery and mastery collide. Each card drawn unveils new possibilities, each joker discovered unlocks the potential for outrageous combos that leave even the most seasoned players in awe.

But what truly sets Balatro apart is its ability to captivate, to ensnare the senses and command attention. The gameplay is nothing short of hypnotic  a delicate dance of strategy and chance, where every move is a calculated risk and every victory a triumph of skill. It's a testament to the artistry of game design, a masterpiece crafted with care and precision.

From its sleek visuals to its immersive sound design, Balatro is a feast for the senses. Every pixel is a brushstroke, every note a melody  together, they form a symphony of sights and sounds that transport players to a world where anything is possible.

In conclusion, Balatro isn't just a game  it's an experience. A testament to the boundless creativity of indie developers, it stands as a shining example of what happens when passion meets innovation. So, dear reader, if you dare to challenge your wits and indulge in the forbidden thrill of underground poker, look no further than Balatro. It's a journey worth taking, a game worth savoring, and an experience that will leave you utterly, irrevocably spellbound.

1. Shop RNG, You need an economy joker or tag early otherwise you can't scale enough, and an Xmult joker later on to meet the high scores as +mult no longer scales enough ( Ihad a time where I spent all my money rerolling with 4 shop slots, 6 rerolls with no xmult joker, and then lost the run even though I made the correct decision)

[h1] Balatro Review: [/h1]

[b] TLDR: If you like Poker and you like Rogue-like deck builders. This game is a must buy.  [/b]

[h2] Rating:  5.0/5.0 [/h2]

[h2] Detailed Review: [/h2]
This game came out on my birthday and I spent more hours on this game than I did actually working my full time job. I found out about this game a month ago and didn't get to play the demo until NextFest. I put over 20 hours into the demo and completed it, but still played. On release day, I was amazed to find that it had so much content. There's over 10 types of starting decks, 100's of Jokers, and various cards/combinations. 

The goal of the game is to reach the final Ante (level). In the demo there were only 5 Antes, but in the full game to "win" you must beat 8 Antes. However, after completely 8 antes there is actually an endless mode where you can test the limits of the deck that you've been building. 

When you first start the game you are asked to choose a starting deck. Each starting deck has it's on starting "ability" and each Ante there is a Small Blind, Big Blind, and the Boss Blind. There is a set number of Poker Hands you are able to play from cards you are dealt. Usually, the rarer hands give better scores. Each blind there is a set score to reach to defeat the blind and failure send you back to the main menu. The higher the Ante, the higher the set score or base score there is to beat. Each Boss Blind features a unique Boss with special abilities/debuffs, which could immediately ruin your run. Beating a blind gives you some money and allows you to visit the Shop.

Deck building is extremely fun in this game and amount of combinations is endless. In the Shop, you can find options to improve your starting deck/run with Jokers, Tarot Cards, Planet Cards, and Vouchers for a price. Jokers have their own unique abilities that can improve your cards, type of hand played, multipliers to your score, and more. Tarot cards and Planet cards are consumables. Tarot cards have abilities to alter your deck and improve your deck. Usually allowing you to enhance(buff) your cards, generate money, create/copy card, and more. Planet cards are used to upgrade specific Poker hands that you may gravitate to (probably why they are called planets... I can't believe it took me this long to realize). Last but not least, Vouchers are unique cards that apply a buff that range from increasing your Hand size or increasing money gained. Only one can be found per Ante, but I don't want to spoil you any further!

If you made it this far... Thanks for reading! Just buy the game!
All skill no luck

Great roguelike. Don't be put off if you're not into gambling or poker. It uses poker hands, but you don't have to know them (easily accessible list that details them), and I wouldn't really call it gambling, though it has all those themes and is based largely around luck and probability.

It's an extremely addictive, faster version of a game like Slay the Spire, but with (to my feel) more interesting variety because of the Jokers +  cards like Tarots and Planets. 

The tutorial is a bit lacking, and there's no easy way to replay it if you wanna repeat it. If you do this, turn OFF Steam Cloud saves, and delete the game folder in %AppData%\Roaming\, run the game (it will recreate the folder), then turn Steam Cloud saves back on (you have to turn it off before deleting or it loads the cloud save).

At first I didn't really get it. Make the best solo poker hand you can. Meh. 

But the real game is in everything that is built *around* that concept. The careful selection of joker cards to customize your strategies. Balancing the money you spend on upgrading hand values and rolling the dice on a wide variety of interesting card attributes that change the rules of the game. 

This game takes the opposite approach to what you typically see in a rogue like. Normally the gameplay itself is where the fun is had and the upgrades and choices add flavor and interest to it. In Balatro's case the gameplay itself is really quite simple and bland. But its the upgrades and choices that ARE the game.

Pretty disappointed in Balatro. I started with the demo version in anticipation of the full release, and absolutely adored the game. In the demo, you play quite a few Antes up to the 100k point boss and when you beat it, the demo ends. Pardon me for assuming, but that would imply that there is more to the game than the 100k boss.
This is not the case. The full game also ends after the 100k final boss. You are given the option for "endless mode" afterwards, which rather than the normal linear scaling you get playing through the game the first time, you get 3-4 more Antes before you're expected to hit 100,200,000 points to beat the boss. The scaling becomes exponential. It feels designed to stop you from playing. Rather than getting to explore more of the game, trying different things out, and seeing how strong you can grow, it throws a brick wall at you. 
You are forced to have a godly set up to keep going after the 100k point boss - which I remind you, was the final boss of the demo - except now you get to pay $15 to do it.
This means the demo basically IS the full game. I have played for 5 hours now, and have beat the "final" boss numerous times at this point, and never once was it an enjoyable experience in endless mode. Having a really exciting set up where I'm scaling off of all kinds of mechanics, playing 300k point hands, and then the boss going from 1,120,000 -> 10,200,000 requirement in exactly 3 rounds is absurd. 
This was the first game in a long time I was genuinely excited to pick up. I kept trying and trying to find where the joy from the demo was, but the joy of the demo was the idea there was a whole world behind the curtain; I paid $15 to find out it was a brick wall.
This is the GOTY 2024, you can end the year now.

I do recommend this, naturally, but my review is not so clear cut. I would say 6.5/10 on my personal scale where anything above 5/10 is recommend. (so 7.5 IGN score)
THE GOOD:
The game is overall very solid roguelike built on the top of poker scoring rules.
It has ton of gameplay options, replayability, and fun combinations and options to deck your deck.
Some combos are really crazy.
Overall very fun and addictive.
Great visuals, card tactility, sound and atmosphere.
THE BAD
It is using poker rules, but doesnt translate good bits from poker such as folding, betting or all ining.
There is no real foe you play against, just artificial score goals.
One bad draw can ruin a good run.
One bad boss can ruin a good run with no way to prepare for it.-Boss rerolling should be a default option.
Overall, RNG is too strong-there are too many options/Jokers to branch and too little opportunity on how shop rolling can even help you. 
The "number game" is too highrolly on both ends, sometimes making some runs a joke and sometimes totaly discrediting good plays simply because cicrcumstances turn them irrelevant.

So overall, a very good game in its core, unlike endless Slay the Spire clones, with very original and fun concept! Too bad it has heart of a slot machine rather than its inspiration, poker!

I would say surely worth 15 bucks, but do not give to the overwhelmingly positive reviews. There is tad bit too much focus on quantitty and shop RNG and lack of the refined number game, that the king, Slay the Spire, still wins in uncontested.

Only complaints are that the game is more luck dependent than most other roguelikes, and your "characters" (decks) aren't very unique. Great game that stands out in an oversaturated genre.

tl:dr Game is really good. For $15 it is an absolute steal. I very rarely feel passionate enough about a game to really spread the love through a review, but this game is really something special.

I've played for about 50 ish hours including the 2 demo's I participated in. My first real win that I was happy with was stacking supernova with high card and getting 18k per round. That was when I still played the game at a surface level. Let me tell you, the ways to play the game are insanely high. You wanna add 100 cards to your deck? There's a joker to help with that. You want to have exactly 30 kings and nothing else? There's some jokers that can help with that. You wanna play around steel and gold cards and holding valuable in hand buffs? Theres a few jokers for that too. All this on top of the base expected ways of playing the game.

In the demo's the way people were getting the highest scores were with getting one of the 3 "secret" poker hands that the game lets you use and using 2-5's with glass and red seals with the joker "Hack" and getting 150 billion points or something like that. With ALL of the new content and all the ways to play being increased in intensity, you can hit those somewhat regularly with the right lucky combo. You want to see how crazy the game can get? Watch some of the very dedicated content creators or follow along with your favorite creators as they begin to play it.

Without giving away too much, yes, the game is really good and can be played for hours by accident. If you're having trouble, play a few rounds of the basic deck and try to run the deck that starts you with an additional 10 gold. It's probably the easiest deck with the lowest requirement to think about. I really enjoy the game and I know most people who read this will too. If this is on sale, just remember what I said above. This is a steal of a game for base price. Imagine the value at 10% or 25% off.

People will say Balatro is "addictive," but what that means is: (1) it's easy to learn, (2) the strategy is as deep or shallow as you want, and (3) the roguelike randomness means every game is a bit different.

Best deck builder I have played since Slay the Spire.

I have never played a game for so long, in the first 3 days of owning it. 

Balatro is a masterpiece, everything from the music, to the unlockable content, to the difficulty spikes and challenges along the way, they all scream ADDICTIVE. The music is extremely catchy and I find myself humming along to it, I'm not even halfway done the game yet, its been a smooth 25 hours that definitely does not FEEL like 25 hours put in. 

The art style makes you feel joy and butterflies when you see a rare joker in your shop, or even the sound effects from getting something like a poly-chrome joker, everything about this game is perfect and I don't ever see myself getting tired of it. The best part, is that its super beginner friendly! 

I know most people do not know the game of poker, or the hands it holds, but this game does not hold your hand, nor does it punish you for your lack of knowledge, everything is laid out very clean in the user interface and joker cards, save for a few, are very well explained in what they do. I could keep going on and on.

This game is a must try for anyone, music lovers, rogue-like enjoyers, deck building lovers, and even just casual gamers will all have a blast! Truly a special release, thank you LocalThunk for this 10/10 masterpiece.

For quite a few years now, my tier list for the Roguelike Deckbuilder genre has been:

S: Slay the Spire
A: Monster Train
B-D: Everything Else

For those that care, 200+ hours and A20 cleared in StS, 140 hours and A24 cleared in Monster Train

Balatro is definitely in A tier for me, maybe S tier. Here is my reasoning why:

 - Upcoming threats are communicated to the player in advance to allow them to prepare. In Slay the Spire, these were the Act bosses, Monster Train had the 3 bosses, and Balatro lets you view your Ante boss 3 rounds in advance. Games like Griftlands really failed in this regard imo, so I'm glad Balatro learned from those mistakes.
 - Threats are meaningful. In Slay the Spire/Monster Train, different bosses required different strategies and punished decks that were too one-dimensional (this is a good thing). Balatro works similarly, with some really nasty modifiers that can end a run if you don't leave some flexibility.
 - There are a variety of viable builds that can win you runs, or at least Balatro has variety in the first couple difficulties.

However, the thing that really pushes Balatro into the S tier for me is the spectacle. Slay the Spire and Monster Train aren't ugly games, but they aren't gorgeous. Balatro is. You really have to play it to get what I mean, but the audio and visual cues make the gameplay loop feel incredible.

If you're a fan of the genre, just drop the $15 and go for it.

As a fan of Slay the Spire, this game looked boring to me, lacking cool enemies or weapons; instead, it featured traditional playing cards. While I enjoy poker, I couldn't see the excitement in a single-player "poker game". Nevertheless, I purchased it merely out of curiosity, fully intending to request a refund within the two-hour window. However, I am addicted! Even if I had the option to refund it now, I wouldn't.

Although it draws inspiration from Poker, this game is not your typical card game. It offers a significant amount of freedom, and the combos/synergy you'll uncover, create an entertainment value that's difficult to describe. If you have any interest in roguelike deck builders, I highly recommend giving this game a try.

Truly an innovative take on the rogue-like genre. Every time I start a run there's a real excitement at what possibilities I'll find next. Can't recommend sinking your teeth in to this one enough.

It's insanely addictive. Last time a game made me play deep into the night and skip sleep was when HADES relesed... It's soothing, fun, engaging and the desire to do 'one more run' is indeed mighty. I allows for a wide plethora of builds! I won on pairs, two pairs, three of a kind, flushes... There is no combination you cannot squeeze a win out of. However it is important to notice that RNG can be quite brutal and resetting runs is a frequent thing. 

If there is one pain point right now is that it feels like a reverse rougelite - in most other rouges you feel you get better and stronger as you progress and unlock more things; Here unlocking more cards means that RNG can punish you even harder, as now getting Jokers and cards fitting your build or idea of a build is even harder, with a stroke of luck often needed to shape a build up to carry you through.

Other than that, it's addictive as fuck and twice as fun.

An incredibly well-designed game that isn't just an instant classic; it's the best roguelike deckbuilder yet made.  Yes, better than Slay the Spire, which the Balatro dev (just one guy!) notably [i]didn't[/i] play, thereby creating a game that's actually unique and not just "StS with a coat of paint" like so many other titles in the genre.

I can't recommend it enough, but I also can't stress enough how dangerous this game can be, especially if your superpower is gambling addiction or ADHD hyperfocus.  It really drives home why casinos are lacking both clocks [i]and[/i] windows, because I've already had two nights in a row where "I'll just play a few hands before bed" has turned into "oh $#!& the sun is coming up".

Send help...but first, send some negative jokers, so I can multiply some multipliers and finally try to crack Ante 11.  Or beat the next difficulty.  Or try the new deck I just unlocked.  Or...

Well, you get the idea.  A ridiculous amount of content for $15, and if you're here reading reviews, just buy it.  An absolute must-play.

A breakdown 60 second breakdown that's not a copy-pasta:

Positives:
-Great core gameplay loop even if you're not familiar with poker hands.
-It's VERY easy to sit down and play this for hours and hours. There's enough variety in deck builds to keep the game fresh for probably 30-40 hours (conservative estimate) if you wanted to try every kind of build.
-The game does almost every thing right in a deck building game. It's 100% worth trying for at least the 2 hours to see if it's a game you'd enjoy playing.

Cons:
-The music loops ends less abruptly as it pulls you out of the immersion.

Request from dev:
-I wish the game was clearer on telling you exactly how the hand would play out after taking all your jokers into account. It can be hard to tell in the end game if it's better to use a card that gives you +30 coins, or x4 multiplier.
-More music loops! If you had different music for each deck, that'd be the chef's kiss on this great game.
-I feel like the UI could be better when checking the deck to see what cards are in your deck.

Balatro is an excellent deck builder roguelike whether you like poker and/or roguelikes. I first played as someone who has not played a lot of poker, does not know poker hands and is not a fan of poker but does like deckbuilders. What makes the poker aspect to Balatro so genius is it works so well as a vehicle for the main ideas and mechanics of the game. Poker players get drawn in by the body of the vehicle while deckbuilder and roguelike connoisseurs get drawn in by whats under the hood. The demo was another genius move as while it was missing content, it felt like a full game already which draw myself and many others I know in immediately.

The music is perfect to make you feel relaxed but not distracted (although maybe unlockable records to change music could be cool), the builds in the game are extremely diverse and full of synergy, the starting decks all feel like they give you a new way to approach making a new build and the game feels different enough every run to make you want to play over and over again

Different profiles allowing people to do speedruns and challenge runs is a extra sweet bonus

There are so many pluses to this game and I am sure I'll keep finding more, I highly recommend giving this a try

If I was to give any fault to Balatro, it would be this:

1) The Arm (Blind) feels extremely punishing as just seeing it coming up can feel like your run is already over. it bodies so many builds by reducing the level before scoring and still being a x2 base. It maybe should be reduced to 1.5x. I honestly feel like every other blind can be played around but the Arm just feels like you either have what you need to beat it or you lose.

EDIT: The Arm did get patched same day I wrote this so now it can't level a hand down below lv1 so that feels a lot more fair now

2) I don't know quite how the anti calculates the next set of blinds after you beat a boss blind but I went from a 20M boss blind to a 300M small blind in endless. The jump seemed a bit unfair as it meant my build that was handily beating all blinds with a single hand of my worst hand suddenly lost immediately after using all 4 of my hands and still only being 151M/300M. My best hand was 44M. I think the jump is a tad high and means you have to have a very specific game breaking build to keep climbing. Endless in this sense doesn't really feel like endless it just feels like a test to see if your build is in the top like 10% of best builds ever made by anyone in the game.

The only reason I really have a problem with this is because in any endless mode in games where you build up synergies or builds of something whether it be decks or builds in roguelikes, defenses in tower defense games, armies in RTS etc One of the most fun things is getting the time to keep working on that build to get it to its peak. Maybe the build your playing is only in the top 50% of the best builds anyone has ever played but its a fun build that you enjoyed and to get into endless and to get utterly destroyed in just a few rounds hurts.

[h1] THIS GAME IS ADDICTING!! [/h1]

Easy to learn and hard to master, as every good strategy game should be. After putting 40 hours in the last 3 days, I know a thing or two about the mechanics. However, run after run I find myself using new strategies and synergies that I hadn't thought of before. I was worried that this game would turn into a "collect a card" simulator (looking for the same combo every time), but every build has some viability to at least ante 8.

[b] YES THERE'S SOME LUCK INVOLVED [/b] I mean no crap, its a poker based game, but they do a fantastic job balancing the RNG out where just like real poker, [b] SKILL [/b] prevails in the end. 

I'm excited to see where the developer takes this game moving forward, he's already said he expects to support the game for years!

This has potential to become one of my favorite roguelike games of all time.

(Slay the Spire still clears)

This is the kind of game that overwhelmingly reinforces the monkey part of your brain that likes seeing numbers go big and makes you get upset when numbers no go big.

I was introduced to this by YouTuber Hotcyder: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dwSifK7FTvk, and was fascinated by the idea of "Baby's First Roguelike", which is counter intuitive, as roguelikes aren't designed to hold your hand.  Well... Balatro doesn't.  It's tutorial drops you into the game, shows you how it works... and leaves.  It doesn't matter if you luck out to the 8th ante or fall on your face in the 2nd, it assumes you will fail, and anticipates your return.  But the beauty of this one is how addicting it is and how quick it is to get back into the fray.  You unlock Jokers and Decks the more you play that can improve your performance, and can even adjust your difficulty if you're getting froggy; they know you want to try to win big or go home.

It's actually really cool to see how positive this game's reception has been for such a devilishly simple premise; poker, but its all about seeing how far you can run with what you got.  And unlike legitimate casinos, it encourages deck swapping and card cutting.

Balatro is a game that first came onto my radar when content creator Northernlion tried the demo some 6~ months ago. I noted it as an interesting concept, but thought little of it at the time.
Now, with the full release, I can say with confidence that [b]Balatro is one of the best games I've played in a very long time, and will more than likely be my personal 2024 GOTY.[/b] While this review is long, I believe it should provide a detailed look at the best that Balatro has to offer.

I would like to consider myself a roguelike veteran. I've sunk many hundreds of combined hours across genre classics like The Binding of Isaac or FTL, alongside many slightly more obscure releases like Noita, Nuclear Throne, and Monster Train, ranging well across to award-winners like Hades, Slay the Spire, and Inscryption. Of these games, I have 100%-ed Gungeon, Throne, Hades, and Isaac (with Repentance). I note this experience not to show off, but to add weight to the following statement:
[b]Balatro, to me, is the compulsion of the roguelike distilled into its purest form, and has instantly entered the upper echelon of what I would describe as the shining examples of the genre.[/b]

The game does so many things right that it would be difficult to list them all, so I'll pick out a few personal favourites.
[list]
	[*]Balatro's atmosphere, simplicity, and design are so well done that my partner - a self-confessed "casual" who occasionally plays Animal Crossing - sat at my computer, played two runs, and immediately went home and bought a copy on their Switch. I can't think of a higher vote of confidence, if my constant recommendations to play Outer Wilds aren't enough.
	[*]The game's mechanics are easy to understand and compelling to the point of obsession. The entire concept invites you to learn the rules just to turn them inside out. I've built winning runs around every single hand, from the lowly High Card to the heady Flush Five. You'll be putting together synergies on the fly you didn't even realise were possible, only to beat the final boss playing a single hand after carefully constructing your perfect combo.
	[*]The pixel art, with one exception, is all created by the single developer and is gorgeous throughout  - with zero exceptions. It has been a long time since I have enjoyed the art of a game so directly, presented in such an enjoyable way. Every single deck, joker, blind, and background sports art that is a joy just to look at, and every single detail is legible. Once you've got yourself that polychrome glass ace with a red seal, you won't even squint to tell it apart from other cards.
	[*]Balatro has replayability in spades, and that's an understatement. 15 starting decks all have unique and masterfully designed abilities, and each can be brought up through 8 stake difficulties, similar mechanically to Ascensions in StS. The difficulty curve is finely tuned and just right, though there is a spike between stake 4-5. If 120 total stakes wasn't enough, 20 challenge runs provide special starting scenarios with unique rules to shake up the formula.
	[*]If you're a completionist like me, Balatro might even be too much. Every single one of the 150 jokers tracks whether you've won with it on each stake difficulty, distilled into a progress bar on how many of the 1200 stickers you've collected. I'm going to be playing this one for quite a while.
	[*]The progression and rate of unlocking things is just right. The first few runs all supply you with a swathe of new content, right when the thrill of discovery is highest, and this rate simmers down as you become more comfortable with the game's systems and mechanics. At that point, you can start working towards unlocks that ask you to do more specific tasks to help fill out that joker collection. Memorable examples include discarding a royal flush, or beating the game while only playing half the rounds available.
[/list]
If it wasn't already clear, I am of the opinion that Balatro is outstanding and far beyond the quality of many AAA games released in recent times. For a single developer to have created a product as wonderful, polished, and plain enjoyable as this is a testament to the fact that there are still exceptional developers doing equally exceptional things with their ability. I cannot wait to see what LocalThunk does next, but I have to admit I hope it's a paid expansion to my favourite game since Outer Wilds.

Just wanna drop this so I can reflect back some day on how quaint it was that my total playtime hours was under three digits.

Update 2/21/24, evening:
I am seeing floating poker cards when I close my eyes and attempt to sleep.

Update 2/22/24, morning:
Had a dream about a six-of-a-kind hand. Woke up screaming. Wife thought someone was breaking into the house.

Update 2/23/24, evening:
Work has kept me from playing Balatro all day, but it cannot stop me from thinking about it. I have begun formulating several theoretical models for playing a variant of Balatro with real, tangible playing cards in the event war or climate change render our world a post-electricity apocalyptic wasteland and I am unable to play Balatro digitally as God intended.

tl;dr Balatro is amazing, you should buy it.

Okay, that's out of the way. Now, I wanna use this space to talk about my favourite part of Balatro: the variety of challenges.

You want to beat a normal game with a normal deck? Go for it. That's great. Your deck will probably look pretty standard.
You want to beat a game with a weird deck? Sure. Enjoy your weird deck.
You want to get to the end of endless mode? No problem, you can build your deck for that as well. Good luck, you'll need it.
You want to play a standard game with restrictions to make it harder? No problem, each starting deck has a difficulty ladder.
You want to play a game with restrictions AND get to the end of endless mode? Sure, we won't stop ya.
You want to tackle some bizarre challenges with really specific rules? Yup, we've got that too.

This flexibility is what makes the game special. Balatro is a game I can reach for when I want a quick 20 minute challenge OR a grueling 2 hour mathfest. The mechanics are the same. Balatro doesn't care how you play it, which is why you should play it.

I was initially offput by Balatro. Actual normie playing cards? CRT overlay with fake artifacts? Get outta here.

Despite that a friend suggested I try it, and I'm thankful I did because there is no doubt in my mind this is a new indie game classic. Balatro will cause you to lose track of time, it is a joy to interact with (loads fast, responsive to input almost always), and has an aesthetic that just vibes.

If that isn't clear enough: I think most folks looking at game reviews on Steam will enjoy this game. So who would I not recommend the game for? Folks who don't enjoy deckbuilders, those who prefer roguelikes with more of a grindy progression, gamers who primarily enjoy story based games, and those primarily interested in direct competitive multiplayer games.

Lastly, here's some minor nitpicks:
1. Would love to see keyboard shortcuts for playing the game without a mouse.
2. I've only won the first couple of difficulties, but I've found nearly all runs become flush or straight based.
3. With at most 3 rounds per ante there often isn't enough time to counter play the upcoming boss. Some runs just end when a challenging boss appears in the second or third ante and I haven't had a chance to make my deck flexible yet. It's entirely possible there's a skill issue on my side, but I'm not convinced most runs are winnable even at the lower difficulties.
4. It becomes hard to manually score hands later in runs to decide which of two options is better to play.
Fantastic deck builder, build variety feels really varied and the scaling means you're often on the line between crazy success and immediately losing.

This game is simple but deceptively nuanced.
There's a level of layered interactions possible that I haven't seen since games like Binding of Isaac (though of course, in a completely different way from that game.)

It takes the economy building of the more recent autochess genre and combines it with the casino tilting act of counting cards. There's a ton of ways to manipulate the deck in your favor as the game slowly starts revealing it's hand to you.
It's a sweet balance between managing often limited resources, adapting on the fly and rigging the system, there's nothing like going for a strategy and bending the game to your will to make it pave your path to success. It's awesome.

I wanted to like Balatro, I really did, but unfortunately, recent experiences leave me with a bad taste in my mouth. [h2]Balatro, on the surface, SEEMS like a fun game of optimizing and deck building and pulling off crazy combinations, but unfortunately, it actually turns into a game of "do lots of math and equations repeatedly to make sure your score is what you expect it to be," especially deep in a run.[/h2] Personally, I don't enjoy doing tons of math just to play a game, so if you don't either, I advise that you stay away from this game, much as it's fun initially.

On top of that, Balatro has a very fun gameplay loop, but very poor explanation. How to win, for example, is never explained anywhere (but poker hands, something far more people will be familiar with, are explained in great detail), nor is the exact effect of certain mechanics like the significance of rounds vs ante, etc.

Initially, the game is fairly straight-forward, but the more joker combinations and consumable cards you use, the more it deviates from standard poker and into its own game. That's all well and good, but there is a noticeable lack of communication with the player, with the game seemingly expecting you to do the math by hand. A straight is worth X points, plus the points on the cards, but when you have 6 jokers interacting with it and adding +149 chips, then also +10 +5 +1.5 x1.6 multi, and whatever other different values, it becomes a nightmare of math to try and figure out how much you're going to score, and the game does nothing to help you calculate this.

I made suggestions in the Balatro discord about these aspects and was met with outright hostility. How DARE anyone wish for information clarity? I was leaning negative in my review already because of the lack of information, but that has pushed me over the edge.
[h1]If you want to do math constantly, Balatro is a game for you. If not, stay away.[/h1]
(because god forbid we introduce the OPTION to have the game give you a loose score estimate automatically, on an opt-in basis, that would be FER THE CAZUALS)

I wish I could refund my copy, but alas, I'm past the two hour mark. Hopefully, this review can help others like me who don't enjoy doing constant math from making the mistake of buying this game. It's not "just a fun deckbuilder," and there's way too much "do the math yourself or you'll be off by 10 points and screw yourself over" to find it enjoyable after the first few rounds.

Cleverly designed and dangerously addictive mashup of the roguelike and autochess formulas with a memorable presentation/soundtrack (even if it is only like one song on loop). Perfect casual game with lots to do/unlock--absolutely worth the asking price.

Having already beaten most of the higher difficulties and gotten completion marks on most of the decks (analogous to characters/classes in a roguelike), I can tell you that this game does suffer from some balancing and difficulty issues. Runs will often be crushed in the first couple stages if you don't get the right RNG, especially brutal on higher difficulties. A relatively small class of top-tier jokers (passive items) utterly dominate the tier list and you'll likely find yourself using many of the same ones in repeat wins, as the far larger library of more situational jokers often prove straight-up unusable by comparison unless you get a very particular set of synergies. It's closer to Slay the Spire than something like TBoI in this way, as the lack of skill-based mechanical gameplay underpinning the build system can make it feel a bit one-note and helpless on many runs.

With all that said, there is plenty of fun and variety to be had here--it's a fantastic product well worth playing made particularly impressive as it has all been put together by an inspired solo dev whom I fully expect to support the game going forward with balancing updates and more content.

This game is very simple and hard at the same time. You don't need to understand poker to have fun with this game. Its completely offline. The whole basis of the game is to combo cards and beat the set score. On the final stage of each "ante" there is a random debuff that spices it up. Also, this is not a collection game. You unlock cards for the chance to buy them in all preceding runs. Its kind of like Deep Rock Galactic Survivor in how your upgrades (jokers and buffed cards) only last for a single run.
  I highly recommend this game to players of all ages and "genres". I'm not much of a strategy gamer. The only games I have really ever played in the strategy genre are Hearthstone and TFT. Yet, i can not help but have fun. There is hours and hours of fun to be had, and at 15$ you would be silly not to get it...

Fun little poker game with loads of possible builds available. The basic premise is that you need to play good enough hands to earn enough chips to beat the current blind. There are many modifiers available, such as making specific cards more valuable, increasing the base score and multiplier of certain combos, and modifying the number of each card in your deck. All that and more are available from the shop.

While the sheer variety of builds is a strength, it is also a double-edged sword. You have to go with whatever the shop decides to offer you, but with so many things available, it's hard to work toward a specific build. More common hands like flushes and two pairs are safer, but it gets boring playing those same builds over and over again.

The concept is great, but I think it could do with more content beyond just the base levels (maybe add a story?) as well as improving build variety and consistency.

This game is so fucking good.

The aesthetics, overall vibe, music, and gameplay concept are so appealing right out of the gate. Then the cool ass synergies & mental gymnastics over probability really reel you all the way in. The game starts off super addicting, watching number go up super satisfying. Then the game challenges you with unique challenges in the boss blinds, which are usually* very cool.

Despite all that, if I could give this game a rating, it'd be a strong 7. Unfortunately, the game is way too hard and a bit RNG based. I'm all about the challenge of juggling probability & risk/reward, but sometimes it genuinely feels like you were destined to lose. Every time I play this game I get the coolest synergies that I'm always super hype to play, but always lose just near the end without the satisfaction of winning a run. I think the game's base difficulty is a little too hard, in my opinion. I got a synergy all about thinning my deck to only be Aces, along with Ace synergy, 5 of kind synergy, and even tarot card duplication joker's. Yet I still lost because the RNG had decided it to be. 9 Aces out of 30 cards and I couldn't get a single one when I needed it.

In short, this game has really good high points, yet some really bad low points. The good outways the bad, though, and I feel myself getting better at juggling the probability problems every run I do. I trust the game dev will only improve this game as time goes on, so luckily it's only up from here.

Loved the demo. Enjoying the full game, but the full game is a lot less balanced (read too difficult). They need to nerf some of the blinds, the Arm needs to be deleted from the game, worst blind design IMO. I had a lot more fun playing the demo, I find myself a lot more frustrated with the full game. Jokers need rebalancing, some rare jokers are dogshit, if you're unlucky you'll see only shitty common jokers into the late game and just die. Sometimes it feels like the game picks a blind to counter your current build. So many jokers are useless and not worth the cost they come with or their downfalls. 

Buff positive effects, nerf some of the blinds, re-classify or buff uncommon and rare jokers. Most grow effects grow far too slowly to be useful/worth the investment.

Really fun, but needs a lot of love before it's back to the quality of the demo, lots of the new content in the full game feels un-playtested. I love roguelikes based on skill, and churning thru run after run due to luck and or poor play testing on release is annoying. Will update if the game gets the balancing attention it needs. Dark Souls is fun cuz it's hard but skill can get you through most of the difficulty, Balatro feels entirely too RNG-based right now. The demo felt MUCH better and I had much more consistent results.

I'd put up a mixed review if I could.

The core mechanisms of Balatro are really fun and engaging. Building Poker Hands which give you points, and needing to score a certain amount of points each Round are pretty fun ideas. The way that these are modified by Jokers and Tarot cards in particular are very satisfying, though I will say that some of these are more fun than others.

That being said, what holds Balatro back for me at the moment are the following elements:

1. The scaling in the game is absurd. The amount of free multipliers and chips you can get from Joker setups ends up meaning that the actual Poker element really falls into the background. On a recent run, I found myself stressing over the fact I couldn't make a good Poker Hand, but even my "High Card" ended up scoring me nearly a third of what I needed for the round purely off the strength of my Jokers. The reality is that I probably reached the point where it was impossible for me to lose the round, no matter how badly I played my hands...and that was against the final boss!

2. The game very much rewards you for going super hard on one strategy. There are plenty of different types of approaches you can take, but once you've picked one, you're basically going to making the same types of hands over and over again. Often, rather than thinking about what I can possibly make with the hand I'm given, I'm just discarding the same cards over and over to play the same cards over and over.

3. Absurd balancing. This is particularly the case for Jokers and Bosses. Some bosses are completely trivial and can almost be ignored, while others threaten to end your run without much you can do about it. In the same way, some Jokers will give you a minor bonus (say +8 multipler if you play a pair), while others will simply give you completely ridiculous bonuses for playing a certain way (in one run, I ended up with +500 chips every hand and a +45 multiplier....off common Jesters). 

To be honest, I think my complaints can be summarised as...I like the game more at the start of the runs, and while shopping, but usually by around Ante 4, the Poker element itself is starting to become tedious, because I'm no longer really making decisions during it. I know exactly what I need to discard every turn without consideration, and exactly what I'll play, and I simply need to run through it.

Balatro is still a solid game overall, one that will likely improve with feedback and development, but I find myself not as captured by it as other critically acclaimed Roguelikes (Monster Train, Slay the Spire).

An amazing deckbuilder and roguelike up there with Slay the Spire.

Similarly to Slay the Spire, I think this game has a certain level of depth that only great roguelikes have, where it's fun enough at the beginning, but the more you play it and unlock different decks and difficulties, the game forces you to understand it on a deeper level.

It's one of the best types of roguelikes where you begin to see all of these crazy different combinations and synergies, and all of these tiny details in the mechanics that allow you to experiment, improve, and create unique and interesting builds that change your experience drastically every time you play. Sometimes it doesn't even feel like you're playing the same game from run to run.

It's one of those things where you can't help but just play one run after the next because it feels so fresh every time.

I have played every deckbuilder you can imagine. I played dominion, ascension, slay the spire, across the obelisk, monster train, you name it I have probably played it. I can say, without a doubt, unequivocally, that this is an immediate entry into the running for the greatest single deck builder which has as of this time ever been created. If you have any love for any kind of card game on even the most tangential level, you are doing yourself a massive disservice to not acquire this title immediately. $15, this game should be $30, if not $40. I would pay $30 for a DLC for this game. It is utterly brilliant.

A roguelite card game based on the basic idea of poker. I for one personally am not the best nor am interested in card based games, but because of how points are scored on your poker hand makes the game very easy to understand.

With Balatro being poker based you get the infinite seeming possibilities of what poker hands you get in 52 cards. Throw in modifiers for sets, overall score, cards you have currently in your hand, etc etc there is very rarely a run that you've done prior.

For those who are not familiar with poker, there are guides in game and online showing what kind of poker hands can be used per turn. The concept of probability and applying it to how you play the game is very much a big part of poker, it synergizes well with roguelite elements

I had about 25 hours in the demo before the full release, and with nearly 15 hours post-release at time of writing I can say this:

I dreamed about a poker hand-based roguelike for some time, and this is the game from those dreams, brought to life by the illustrious LocalThunk. If you're into deckbuilders, roguelikes, or the casino aesthetic, this is an easy pickup without much argument. The overall mood of the game is silly, chill, and cerebral, and there are ceaseless permutations of cards and niche mechanical interactions that'll keep you invested for as long as you're willing to watch number go up.

The biggest positive qualities I can comment on in this game are attention to detail and quality of life. This is easily the kind of game that could get bogged down by numbers & calculations, but with a fanciful UI for viewing the remaining cards in your deck without straining your eyes and consistent literal interactions between game elements, the game facilitates letting you trusting your intuition so you can play in a way that's satisfying.

I can tell this is gonna be one of my top-shelf games for a long time, and it's only just released. I think that speaks for itself.

Technical review stuff
The game is ~60MB download, and I think that's pretty cool, as someone on rural internet awaiting a fiber drop. Game asset bloat is a real issue, and this is the opposite. Light, great game.
For some reason, and I think it's because I have steam and Lua installed via scoop, I get a Lua error on startup unless I run it as administrator. Not sure what library it breaks having the game in a non-standard directory, but it did not like it. This is in the release 1.0 version.
It also lost sound output after a Bluetooth reconnection cycle, but that's probably a Windows/steam issue.

Now I know what Love2D can do as an engine though. I didn't know it was that versatile and fast for animations. Super well done.

Seems like the house always wins, just like in real life. Unlike real life, however, you can legally play hands that would be considered illegal in a real poker game. This game makes you take everything you thought you knew about poker and throw it out the window, and I'm all for it.

My only caveat with this game is this: [spoiler]The Arm's ability is busted, as it can de-level your hands below the starting level, and thus make them even worse. It seems like it's balanced around having high-level hands and/or the joker that can disable boss blinds, neither of which are likely by the time you encounter it.[/spoiler] But hey, it just means the house has the better odds, just like in real life.

Flush: The Game

Balatro is one of those games that will be described as a Rogue-like deck builder but isn't quite a deck builder (although it has elements of it). It's more akin to the tableau building mechanic of board games, where you are trying to create an engine based on upgrades you bought.

The game is working on two levels. On the strategic level, you have to juggle factors like increasing the base value of your cards (Chips), increasing their Multipliers, and managing your wealth. There is some deck building going on but when you start out with a 52-card deck, adding or subtracting a card isn't going to significantly impact your games on the short-term. Although there are cards that can massively alter your deck, such as changing sets of cards into a different suit.

On the tactical level, it's Poker with players doing a risk assessment with every hand. Sometimes you play a High Card, even though it'll score low, in order to get rid of other cards in your other. At other times, you want to gamble and maximize your earnings, discarding several cards in order to facilitate big plays like Straights and Full Houses.

Quite innovative! Poker's always been this traditional, orthodox card game with virtually no adaptations attempting to twist it. BOOM, this game comes along, transposes, shuffles and radically changes the concept of Poker. Rogue-like Poker??? What in the world.. But, it just works perfectly, so cleverly reimagined. 

This is a sweet, short game you can play anytime, anywhere. There are uncountable ways to build a deck and it will usually be randomly decided however you will advance based on the jokers you will purchase.

This game is definitely played the best when you make your own fun and challenge yourself, as that is where the greatest rewards will be. You can play it safe, though with no compromises and sacrifices will there be no wins.

This game's a 10/10, no doubt. I struggle to mention any negatives and I am excited to see future additions to this game.

Insanely fun game - don't be discouraged by the poker deck, all you literally have to do is just play poker hands that can be easily referred from the menu while the rest of it... is just pure roguelike madness.

Seriously, this game oozes with style, theme and excellent ideas that I have not seen implemented in other rogue-like deckbuilders. 

However, I will say that after 10 initial hours, I do feel like there's inconsistency between the first few rounds because you heavily rely on the shop and what good options it offers. Otherwise, you must either play the round or skip it for a reward (that also be be bad sometimes), so if you are going to play this game - my advice would be to always make sure you have at least 1 Joker that can provide a multiplier or additional chips to have smoother experience.

But yeah, the amount of crazy decks I've built is shocking and I've barely scratched the surface. Some players are saying that Flushes and Two Pairs are dominating the meta right now but I just finished a run with Straight decks and was consistently scoring 250+ chips thanks to a combo wombo of Jokers I've acquired, while other on another run I focused on maximized Four of a Kind deck and it also worked! 

So yeah, game is gud, if you're a roguelike deckbuilder fan and want a quality product with a fresh new idea - check this game out. 

Also, this game was made by one dude. You gotta support those lonely hermits who dedicate their life to crafting wonderful indie games.

If you like TCGs, Gambling, or Roguelikes, this game hits all those so hard. Absolute insanity as you master the extremely interesting mechanics of this game as it transforms generic poker into one of the most enjoyable and chaotic experiences ever. This game is one you WILL get addicted to, and the style is so nostalgic as well.

TL;DR: Picture the difference between meth and sugar. Balatro is the same, but for crack cocaine.

[+] Immense variety of builds resulting from complex emergent behavior.

[+] Fun modifiers in the form of alternate decks.

[+] Item unlocking system that feels constant keeps the game fresh.

[-] No perma-progression. (I understand that it would make Ascensions trivial, but it would be nice for endless mode only)

[~] I personally love  the art style, though I do realize that *some* may be negatively affected by nausea and the like.

[-] A bit of item bloat is present. Sometimes you simply don't roll any good passive upgrades (Jokers) to get a build running.

[+] Lovely QOL and UI decisions make the game feel smooth to play. (Speed slider is great, but would like to see 6x as well)

[-] Black deck is hell on earth.

[-] Many of the blinds (Read: bosses) are a far too punishing.

I generally love this type of game but I'm genuinely confused on why this has such high ratings. When playing this game you are 100% reliant on RNG and your ability to reduce the RNG is non-existent. You basically unlock new cards by buying the current unlocked cards in the shop. So your entire strategy starting out should just be to acquire enough money to buy a card the first time so that it will count towards your total 'unlocked cards' which will give you access to more cards. It's an extremely grindy system and I'm already pretty tired of it quite early into the game (3 hours total with about 1 of those afk so far) and I love poker.

I expected it to be in a similar vein to 'Luck Be A Landlord' but this isn't anywhere near as good as that game.

This one is worth maybe $6 at most.
Buy it.

A creative point salad rogue-like that lets you set up some wild and crazy combinations. Lots of interesting decisions about how to best manipulate your odds for the best chances at a high score.

I have two suggestions for the dev:
- The rewards for skipping blinds are pretty bland and get repetitive. I'd love to see more variety here to make it a more interesting decision.
- Some boss blinds and jokers require you to know what hands were recently played. It would be great to have a round recap that breaks down each hand that's been played and a point calculation breakdown. This becomes more of an issue when you save mid-run and try to continue later.

So, i've easily gotten the hang of this game and the jist of it or whatever by now.

I would mostly recommend this game, it has an addictive kind of gameplay with you easily being able to jump in and out of several matches of playing poker by yourself, as the whole point of this game is to play a wacky version of poker where everything is based on you getting enough points based on the hands you play. You can get higher points based on the deck you draft, the line-up of joker cards you have, what you upgrade, some other factors, and most of all RNG.

While it's obviously going to be RNG based being a card-game, it is still pretty unfair in that often you will lose with no counterplay simply because of a boss you fight against, as each end of a 3-part Ante has a "boss" and their modifiers will often instantly lose you the entire match. Losing simply to bad RNG alone is to be expected in other ways such as a bad hand of cards, but some things are too unfair.

Besides that biggest glaring issue, some cards will obviously just blatantly be better than others too whether they be joker-cards or card combinations. You mind as well often just quit the run at a certain point simply based off not getting a good enough line-up of jokers or other buffs, cause there is no way you will win at a certain point.

Lastly, the difficulty scaling is way too much often. The amount of points you are expected to rack-up is statistically highly improbable and should not be expected by the player to win. I should not need to have repeat full-houses, perfect joker card line-up, or even much better just to be able to not lose my entire run.

I would recommend it still, but I would definitely like to see some things balanced to tip things atleast a little more in our favor as the cards are already stacked against us, ha-ha.

[h1]Game Review from 30 Minutes of Play[/h1]
Reminding myself if I should revisit and if you should purchase.

[b]ELEVATOR PITCH: Slay the Spire addictiveness but in Poker Form[/b]
LIKED: I watched so many gameplay videos and reviews, but didn't get the appeal. When I purchased and put in my 30 minutes, I was thinking uh-oh this is going to be an addictive gem.
DISLIKED: The poker theme is approachable but may not appeal to everyone, they might be satisfied with Slay the Spire and be done with any other games in this genre. However, I strongly encourage everyone to buy and try themselves before passing judgement. Also, funky name.

[b]===== Mood After 30mins =====[/b]
 Addicted
 Afternoon delight
 Grindfest
 Frustrated

[b]===== Will I Revisit =====[/b]
 Yes, I aim to 100% complete
 Yes, but only beat the game
 Eventually. Until then, back to the pile
 No, on to other games

[b]===== Price =====[/b]
 Full price worthy
 Discount
 Deep discount
 Pass

[b]Disclaimer:[/b] [i]I'm aware 30 minutes is not enough time to properly review any game. Historically, I'm a big completionist when it comes to gaming, but my backlog will just not die and adulting obligations continue to mount. I needed to find some sense of accomplishment with my backlog other than buying them at great discount. Dedicating at least 30 minutes of play per game will be my arbitrary sense of achievement. It may not justify my gaming spending habits, but I'll suffer less buyer's remorse. Who knows, in 30 minutes I might discover a great game I want to revisit and something you want to purchase. GGs![/i]

Video games don't have to have photo-realistic graphics of a tree or bush to be fun. They can to have a simple premise that with a twist of game dev ingenuity develops into a deeply complex and multi-variant way of exploring and having a good time. Gambling rogue-like with tons of replayability due to the variance of joker, planet, spectral, and tarot cards, with deck manipulation and that when you finally get into a good groove in a run leads to loads of dopamine rushes when you go endless and see those numbers pop.

Even if poker's not your flavor, if you like roguelikes this game might scratch an itch for you.

TLDR: Worse Aces&Adventures.
The dev removed the demo so I have to buy the game to try it out, see how its balanced etc.

The problem with these poker games is that aside from flush and basic stuffs like pairs, other things are simply too unreliable, so it is a challenge to balance the game in a way that makes other builds viable. The thing with this game is, they never made other builds viable. Its not like it is impossible to win with other build, its that the RNG nature of the game means you are straight up handicapping yourself by going other builds and there is no incentives aside from "I haven't done that before".

Other than the elephant in the room that is the gameplay balance, everything else isn't anything remarkable either, every round plays the same except for the "boss" which is too random it feels like bullshit sometimes and there is no storyline or anything like that to really incentivize you to play further after getting the first win. The soundtrack is forgettable too.

All in all, this game isn't terrible, it just hasn't done anything better than other poker theme games. The one game that actually kinda solved the problem I have listed is Aces&Adventures, although even that game feels repetitive after you have figured out every type of decks.

Edit: disabled comments because some of you think it's fair to throw abuse at someone just because they didn't enjoy a game. Fuck the lot of you.

I really want to enjoy this game,  I thoroughly enjoyed the demo, but at the moment, the full version of the game is too hard, to the point of feeling demoralising. I've played over 50 runs in game, and the only one I won was on a selected seed, which the game doesn't count as part of the "runs won".

I fully understand that might be a personal issue rather than a problem with the game, but I've had various friends also say the game is harder than the demo was.

If the game gets updated with some additional difficulty balancing, perhaps an "easy" mode for people like me who suck at roguelikes, and it no longer feels like an impossible task, I'll change my review to a positive one, but until that time, I am just unable to recommend this game.

Played a few hours of this already on the Steam Deck, and I can already say, this is a game that will remain installed on local storage forever. Why? First of all, it's just like 50 MB(as of writing). Also, it's very easy to pick up, and it will be even easier for those that play a lot of poker games, that they will recognize when they have a good hand quickly. If not, you just have to press 1 always available button that will remind you what is a Flush and what is a Full House. Controller Input or Mouse or Touchscreen, they all work. Music is great and relaxing. Overall a very chill card game. 

Some of the bonuses the Jokers, Planet, and Vouchers apply are sometimes not 100% clear, so some trial and error is needed to get familiar with the game. 

I hope the game gets more cards of any time as updates and fixes come in, and if there is a modding community for this game, it's all going to be great.

With a minute shy of 2 hours, I've had a successful run with this game. There are harder difficulties, and multiple decks I could play with, but I'm not feeling very motivated to do any of that. While the gameplay is fun, that's just about all there is to the game, enemies are just some numbers with a (potentially useless) random effect for the bosses,  and that gameplay doesn't feel too different from run to run. 

Compare this to a game like Slay the Spire, where there's random events to encounter, a variety of enemy types with their own charms and character, and 4 different characters that all play completely different from each other, making it more desirable to replay the game with each one. 

This game will stay on my hard drive, I'll pick it up for an hour or so here and there, it's still fun, but I don't think there's enough there to make me want to play non-stop like others are saying
