I'd been looking for a new deckbuilder roguelite, but couldn't find anything that felt new and different. All variations on Slay the Spire.

This is a very simple but different premise. The game revolves around poker hands, but you upgrade your cards and collect 'jokers' to massively change how you play and max out the score. Works really well. Super fun. Super addictive.

There's a nice progression system too of unlocks and challenges. Quite a lot of depth there.

I'm playing on SteamDeck and runs flawlessly plus the controller layout is actually properly integrated and set up with icons etc. In short, plays perfectly with controller/SteamDeck.

Would absolutely 100% recommend if you're into deckbuilders and/or card games and/or poker.

awesome game

Balatro is an absolute masterpiece. It combines everything you love about video poker, deck building (not something I was really into before), and the addictive roguelike loop of learning to hone your skills a bit more with each run.

The retro aesthetics and stellar synth score allow you to melt your stresses away while focusing every neuron into your next play and possibility--all without a timer, pressure, or a competition against others. It's just you, your cards, and the warmth of glorious multipliers sounding off in the background as your score quadruples continuously. I can't recommend Balatro highly enough.

Steam Deck:
Balatro runs perfectly in all aspects--nary a single crash, and it's a delight to play with both the touch screen or gamepad controls. The battery life was barely dipped into during a 3.5 hour session.

I think its easy to misunderstand Balatro.  Even the game itself claims to be a roguelike.  While I wouldn't necessarily dispute that entirely ... Solitaire has always been a roguelike.  Shuffle the cards, a new adventure each time.  What Balatro does that stands out is basically just be Solitaire++.  That's not to discredit it, it's just I think we might have become extremely stupid over the years when "I shuffled the deck of cards" became associated with roguelikedness.  And yet, Balatro is maybe the *most* rogue experience I've had in a while because it actually does what it sets out to do: each run is a new experience.  As a time waster it wins the prize, this is a great game of Solitaire.

I don't know this is a game I would really be inclined to binge constantly, but if I only had twenty minutes this is a perfect way to fill that time.  Just be careful you don't click next run and miss an appointment.

Pretty boring, yeah there's a lot of card combinations but at the end of the day it's just enhancing poker hands. The shaking/crt is sickening and has to be disabled, the music is boring, and the visuals are boring. Gameplay is meh because like I said all youre doing is enhancing poker hands, buy planet cards to make certain hands worth more, get jokers that make certain cards worth more, get spectrals that make certain cards worth more, buy more of specific cards to make more of the hands that you made worth more. There is never a feeling of defeating any boss or objective because it's just score 500 points, ok now score, 1000, ok now 5000, etc. Played through my first run and won super easily defeating the final boss (100,000 wowow) in a single hand.....I've never played a roguelite where I win on my very first attempt knowing nothing about the game.

I could see this being fun for someone who likes playing card games and doing simple math but overall it put me to sleep so I refunded it.

The best spin on Poker yet. A feeling of risk similar to gambling, without the actual risk of losing money. It includes plenty of content and options to keep each run interesting. The variety greatly expands once you dive more into the different card packs available in the shops.  Planets, card-specific modifiers, tarot cards, and as well as a few more,  Each run will always be different than the last as you explore more and more card options. The progression remains consistent, so the first few hands won't be nearly the same as when you're at least 5 'failed' runs deep. If they end up supporting workshop content, or mods in general, this could be the poker equivalent to rogue-lite greats like Slay the Spire, Into the Breach, and maybe even Binding of Isaac.

This is one of the good ones.
Pretty much immediately graduated into the "Genre Exemplar" category for roguelites and card games, personally.

It's full of mechanics that mesh together really well, the gameplay is amazing, and there seem to be a lot of options for build versatility and playstyle. 

The UI is fantastic (special mention to the cards remaining table when viewing your deck in game), the backgrounds are busy enough to add texture and flavor while being simple enough to not distract.

The art is lovingly crafted, immediately recognisable at a glance, highly detailed, and the shaders on the foil treatments are magnificent.

The soundtrack is good, but because the way all of the songs bleed into each other (and the droning organ pad is good but it gets a bit grating being in one of the most common tracks), it can get stale after a few hours. I'm usually a purist when it comes to soundtrack but at hour 6 I'm strongly considering muting it and playing other stuff. So far, that's my only gripe.

Finally, the price seems fair. I can easily see myself getting my money's worth (if I haven't already). I'd suggest trying it - you'll probably be grabbed in the first two hours.

Awesome game by the way. If you loved slay the spire then this will consume you. Its so easy to understand even if you've never played poker. The gameplay itself is super basic so it makes it even more impressive with what the dev managed to accomplish here.

Also not as RNG heavy as one might think. While its true that the odds are always stacked against you, the game gives you plenty of opportunities to make your own luck. If you're going for a full house face or straight flush build then just keep on focusing on adding the needed cards and its basically a guarantee that your opening hands will be viable even when against a blind. There's literally a joker that can improve your luck ratio as well. 

I think the most important thing is to understand how to maximise your mult. Every game is short enough to remember all the buffs in your head when making plays.

I don't think I've ever played a game and not had a single idea of how the game could possibly be improved.  This is the closest thing to a perfect game I think I've played.   The gameplay is satisfying and so intricately balanced, something that is so hard to do in any game, much less a roguelike.  

You have decks that you scoff at (like the all spades and hearts deck) and say "that will be easy" until you hit a boss that shuts down your hearts and it makes you realize how deep the deck building goes in this game.  There is no "win" button, but if you learn and plan, there is still ample opportunity for you to break your deck and get that satisfaction without it feeling cheap (like I said, the deck that seems like it'd be easiest to win with by playing endless flushes isn't just an "I win" deck since you still need to find the right jokers and boss fights).

The jokers, the tarot cards, the upgrades, the deck variety, the difficulty levels not just being "get more score, dummy" (one difficulty step I found so far does do that, but the rest actually modify the rules of the game), it's just all so perfect and has so much replayability.

This is the easiest game recommendation I'll ever make, anybody that has ever enjoyed cards or a roguelike needs to play this one.

Balatro is one of the most polished games I've ever played. It uses a CRT effect and smooth, hypnotic music to put you in the headspace of someone playing video poker late at night in a nearly-empty casino. You are given a hand of cards, and asked to hit a point total in a certain number of hands. You can discard cards you don't like to try and improve your hand, and you have up to 5 Jokers with various effects to improve your score further. There's a few other moving parts, but that's the basics.

Despite the number of available options the game has in total, it does a good job never overwhelming the player. There's no clocks, timers, or reflexes needed - take as long as you need. And the options available are kept simple and few each time they're offered, but many and complex in the context of all possible builds you could try out. 

For example, there's a Joker card that makes you want to avoid playing face (Jack, Queen and King) cards. This seems simple at first glance, but how you deal with that limitation is a pretty open question. Do you just discard the face cards? Get rid of them entirely? Put effects on them that benefit them staying in your hand? Or maybe all of the above. 

The game isn't easy by typical gaming standards, but by roguelike standards, it's one of the more accessible out there. I've played Hades and Enter the Gungeon for tens of hours each and never beaten a run. I still haven't beaten Slay the Spire with all available characters. Balatro's base difficulty is low enough that I could win from only a few hours of playing. And desipite the large amount of randomness in the game, the level of control you have over both your build over the course of the run and your cards in a moment-to-moment sense gives the a game a sense of being very fair. If I lose, my first thought is, "what could I have done better" and not "wow, that was a cheap death".

Odds are you know if you'll love Balatro. 
Even if you don't, you can catch on very quickly.
Drawing on most of our shared experience with playing cards, the game's mechanics are highly intuitive - make big poker hands.
Flush away all the things one dislikes about poker, for example by giving the player a hand of 10 cards to make a hand with, and allowing you to discard and redraw repeatedly turns the game into a joy.
Pair that with everything compelling about the roguelike deckbuilder genre and you have a bonifide classic.
To pair all the different enjoyable parts of card games, getting new cards - making sets of them - crafting a deck, and upgrading the cards you have, it's absolutely phenomenal.
Heart to Heart, though, some elements of the game are a little unintuitive, like how the hands you play don't need to have 5 cards in them, but the journey of discovering these little quirks of the game is part of the game. 
Straight up, any fan of poker, slay the spire, monster train, Inscryption, magic the gathering, and roguelikes generally needs to have this game. 
And that's no Joker.

Lets get two things out of the way first. 
1. No, this isnt a poker game. It uses poker hands, which are simply card combinations and easy to track in game. 
2. This isnt a Slay the Spire-like (great game but thank god). 

What Balatro is though is one of the best digital card games ever made. It uses a standard 52 deck and then turns cheating into power ups and mechanics that power the games deckbuilding. Its a make number go up game, but the builds and decisions that drive that are addicting and deeply satisfying. 

See, Balatro understands what makes card play fun: variability, strategy, tactics, synergies, combos, and pushing your luck. These are elements that seen in combat oriented deckbuilders, the StS-likes, but here they are made so much more immediate with minimal text, snappy turns, and an intuitiveness that doesnt sacrifice depth. 

Balatro really is a special, hypnotic, and refreshing experience. In a time when it seems like every month a new StS-like comes out, its a relief to see a game prove that not all digital card games have to be attack/defend combat games. Now that Ive said that Im sure its only a matter of time before the first Balatro-like comes out. 

P.S. Turn on 2x speed in the settings. Also like many, I put hours into the demo. And I dont even like playing demos!

How is this so good?

Here's a bit of a hint.
For joker bonuses, a pair counts as any hand that contains a pair, like two pair, full house, and three of a kind on up to five of a kind. Likewise for any joker that buffs a three of a kind hand will count for any of the previous hands aside from pairs, and so on. Planet cards are exempt from this, as they only buff the individual hand type, which can make a massive difference when even a pair of cards can be stronger than a full house.
Work around your strengths, and don't fear losing, sometimes just getting something you haven't acquired before may help for future unlocks.
I really don't think they could have executed this idea any better. From visuals, to sound, to replay-ability, to amount of content. Just the perfect package!

The gameplay is really addictive and because of the numerous amount of modifiers in the game ranging from jokers, to hand levels, the amount of repeatability this game has is quite big. 

Pros:
- Game is easy to pick up, simple but can get complex later on
- It's satisfying watching the numbers go big as you progress in the game, especially with gamespeed set to max
- BGM is comfy
- As mentioned before, the replayability is absolutely there
- Huge variety per run because of the vast number of modifiers
- CRT settings for that nostalgic feeling if you're old like me (!)

Cons:
- Maybe this is just me being new to the game but I feel like some of the common jokers actually scale better later into the game compared to some uncommon ones. But then again the game does not necessarily say the rarer a card the better it is, so it's probably skill issue.
- I wish theres a toggle to temporarily turn off a display of the hand example when checking run info as I usually just look at it to see the multipliers. But this is easily worked around by just simply not hovering over the hand itself.


Overall, an amazing game that is worth more than you pay for it in my opinion.

I bought this based upon my time with the demo version. The demo was great. Everything felt balanced, bosses were genrally tricky but fair, and if you failed a run it felt like it was because you failed to make the best use of what was given to you. Playing the hand you were dealt and such. It rarely if ever felt like I lost because of bad RNG or poor design.

The full game however is a vastly different experience. It's difficult to put up the score you need due to a diluted card pool that has far too many cards that don't contribute to scoring, and several of the bosses will outright kill a run if you don't build specifically for them or the RNG graces you with one of the very few ways to reroll a boss. Most runs now feel like you're at the whim of the luck of the draw more than careful decision making. And this is on the easiest difficulty as well. Honestly, I'd rather just have the demo back but that was taken down. Just as well though, since it didn't really represent the final product.

Balatro is one of the best (if not the best) roguelike games I've ever played, and I've played at least 15 of them for many hours. I sunk 6.2 hours into Balatro on one day, and for good reason. Balatro is the only roguelike deckbuilder I enjoy, not because of the simpler mechanics compared to other deckbuilders, but because of how little getting that perfect build matters. It doesn't feel terrible starting a new run without OP jokers or cards, and even losing is a learning experience. Honestly, If you've sat through this whole review and you haven't bought Balatro yet, just do it. You won't regret it.

The best digital card building game I've ever played. You would think that the poker theme reduce player expression and exacerbate RNG frustrations, but it's actually the opposite. All that is asked of you is to reach ever increasing score caps each round, giving you the flexibility to use your turns and discards as you see fit- and with a relatively large hand count compared to other games and the many variations of poker hands available to you there's usually an option to take. Then you throw in all of the jokers, tarot cards, and planet cards which increase your modifiers, and you can make a wide variety of broken powerful strategies that will scratch the itch of any " numbers go up" fan.
What makes this game so addictive is that it rides the line of chaos and control, where it always feels like you could do something to manage the randomness and come out on top. It's still difficult which makes it worth overcoming, but the creativity and strategizing it allows you to lean into will have you wanting to play just one more round. 10 out of 10 glad i'm addicted to this and not real poker

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31028489-Maddmike/]Maddmike Steam Curator[/url]

https://youtu.be/aXA6E1XJ0iM

Balatro is so excellent that it feels like it was discovered, not created. It effortlessly evokes the brainy strategies of the best roguelike deckbuilders while also tying itself back to a poker theming that all those games were mechanically riffing from anyway.

An approachable UI welcomes players who dont know their flushes from their straights, but theres still plenty of challenge to be found in the management of your deck and economyall wrapped up in an intuitive package that would make your grandpa take pause and watch over your shoulder.

The result is a simple yet compelling deckbuilder thats as infinite and as classic as a deck of 52.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3165517353

Balatro is a roguelike solitaire version of poker. Each run starts by dealing you eight cards and asking you to produce the best five-card-hand you can. Repeat over the course of a few rounds.

Rather than having a table of opponents,  youre attempting to hit a score threshold. Each hand has its own score and its own multiplier. The short term strategy is born from Balatros drawing and discard rules; you get a few free per card mulligans each turn, and in a deckbuilder-like fashion you refuel your hand after each play.

Within your first minute youre being asked to answer strategic questions about your risk tolerance: do you discard a guaranteed hand in pursuit of a better one? Or do you play it safe and work with what you got?

The fact that each card replaces itself on play makes them act as a secondary discard, too. Have a hand thats just short of a flush? Why not open round one with playing a modest pair from different suits and chucking in three other random cards alongside them: even if theyre not contributing towards that pair and its point value, they are freeing up those hand slots and give you greater flush opportunities the following turn. Its not guaranteed to work but thats the beauty of it: youre always looking for little ways to stack the deck in your favor.

That's just one example among dozens where Balatro is constantly giving you decisions in small but provocative ways.

That philosophy becomes multiplied after your first few hands when Balatro exposes you to some of its run-wide systems. You get a shop with booster packs, which sounds corny for a deck-of-52 game like this until it gets coupled with the game's concept of jokers.

These would be your relics or artifacts in a title with a more video-gamey theme, theyre passive bonuses that will stay with you for an entire run and you can hold up to five of them under normal conditions.

One run I got a joker that multiplied my score if I only played three card hands instead of five. Now all of the sudden Im pivoting to a style that boosts three of a kinds and pairs, and flushes are near useless because they force me above that three-card limit by their very nature.

That changed how I looked at those booster packs: now suit was less relevant with flushes off the table, allowing me to target specific numbers and faces to maximize my three-card-hand potential.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3165517772

Almost every joker can warp a game in this way, so you get this long term strategy of crafting good jokers for your deck and crafting good decks for your jokers. Its so deep and so fun, once you start to see all the pieces come together its easy to imagine all the ways you can arrange them to make for truly unique runs every single attempt.

Its a time black hole, the hours just melt in front of you.

Part of that is probably because of how well produced it is, too. Not only does it have a simple, replayable little gameplay style but it also has a presentation that makes infinite play so appealing. Mechanically the blinds are kind of like enemies, but they dont really feel that way. You dont get any smashing or crashing animations into them when you successfully score points, just little bleeps and the sound of stacking chips.

It gives Balatro a very non-confrontational vibe, where the focus is always just you and your cards. Each turned in hand gives you a brief animation of your cards cashing in their point values but also a little visual indicator that shows your jokers boosting their power. It makes it obvious who your load bearing jokers are and the fact that the score acquisition is so multiplication heavy gives you this big explosion of points once every card has done its little dance that makes the result so satisfying.

Beyond just being a game with immediately interesting rules and endless strategy, Balatro is also just a damn good roguelike in the conventional sense, too. The meta progression is a steady increase in options and scope. Youll get more potential jokers, more consumable power ups, and more card types.

There are multiple boss encounters that youll want to start building around, too. They apply modifiers that can be a counter to your exact strategy. One of my first almost successful runs leaned on beefing up easy hands like pairs and giving myself additional hands per round: going for consistent additive plays instead of singularly big ones. Imagine my frustration upon meeting the Needle, an encounter that allowed only a single hand to be played.

Obviously, I lost; but the lesson might not be what you think it was. The standard approach would be to have a more flexible deck next time, but theres nothing wrong with single-mindedness in Balatro as long as you bring insurance: either jokers or consumables that let you re-roll or nullify a boss encounters modifiers.

Theres also thought that needs to be given to the relative strength of your deck. Maybe that consistent two of a kind will get you through the early game, but it may not yield the points you need as the run gets tough (and it literally ups the ante). A strategic pivot into strengthening higher point value hands is always on your mind, and you need to be aware of how much hand manipulation you currently have and if youre ready for that pivot.

Balatro isnt just a loving ode to standard playing card decks but also a subtle homage to cards and collectables more generally. It creates intrigue in opening up a booster pack of regular cards by sprinkling in lots of modifiers. There are lucky cards that have a chance of giving a small bonus in addition to their regular effects, steel cards are incentivized to be held and give multipliers to played hands they arent in, and golden cards help boost your economy.

Holographics, foils, and more are attributes you can find on jokers in addition to their regular behaviors, which give you this exciting boost and maybe a reason to alter strategies into a joker that may otherwise be suboptimal for your deck.

[h2] In Conclusion [/h2]

Balatro does so much with so little. With a deck of playing cards and some powerups, its created a timeless card system with high stakes but low pressure. This game of probability manipulation and strategy is one of the best deckbuilders of all time, and its intuitive playing-card presentation might also make it one of the best versions of Solitaire ever made, too.

I've almost never reviewed a game on Steam because I just never felt like it was worth it.  This game changes everything.  It's 2024 and we have a game with tens of hours of gameplay that takes up 62MB of hard drive space and will practically run on a potato.  

Not only that but the game looks and plays amazingly.  Works with plenty of controllers and works out of the box with the Steam Deck with no issues.  You should buy this game.  You should buy it for your friends and your relatives.  This is old school cards meets new school fun.  Its near infinite replayability just means you're going to get an amazing value for such a cheap game.  I followed this game since the demo went up and was practically begging for the full game to release for an entire year.  Really hope it gets a lot of traction since it's just a great game and I want more developers to take notice.

We don't need fancy graphics, studio quality sound, etc.  We just need a game that we can run anywhere and play nearly anywhere.  Now to hound the developers so I can play this on my phone!

A few hours with the Balatro demo convinced me to buy this game on release, and I can safely say I'll be playing it for countless hours going forward. It's as deep as any of the best deckbuilding roguelikes out there, with a ton of variety in deck construction that makes the game tremendously replayable. I've barely scratched the surface of the unlockable content--can't wait to see what the challenges bring. And, while the poker theme might put some people off, please understand this isn't a poker game. That theme exists as a fresh alternative to battling aliens, monsters, or whatever else you might find as enemies in most roguelikes. I appreciate having a deckbuilder that isn't built around combat, because clearing each blind is as tense as any battle I've had in any of my other favorite games in this genre.

I just bought this game 11 hours ago. 

I often see reviews and there is a lot of hyperbole or just completely unhelpful reviews wasting space. I thought maybe this game was a little sketchy since there were so many positive reviews. It couldn't be legit; could it? 

That's what I was thinking 11 hours ago when I was wondering why I didn't see the demo other people talked about. I put on a really really messed up film on Tubi, which lead down a really dark and moist rabbit hole of stripper zombies. I have been so horrified and scarred by the things I saw tonight, but I couldn't stop playing the game because there was movie left. Or I had to start another movie because I was on full tilt. 

I love poker, I love horror movies. I'm not sure how I'm going to be sleeping now that I have lost half a fargon day playing this. 

Definitely no complaints if I were to not pick the game back up again, I'd still feel like I got my monies worth. It really lives up to the review hype. It is the craziest hybrid but so much better than the other deck building games I've played. I played the pants out of Spire back when I bought it. It doesn't really touch this in terms of addiction. It is easy to keep playing because you unlock more jokers and more decks as you go. I finally backed out because the sun is so bright and my eyes... I shouldn't have done this when I was already only running on 3 hours sleep the last few days, but here I am. 

When I backed out tho, to exit, I did unlock like 5 more Jokers so I'm pretty excited to start playing again.

I initially grabbed the demo of this during Next Fest, thinking it might be a quick time killer at best. Despite the simple and frankly absurd premise of a video poker roguelike, this game is surprisingly addictive.

The level of strategy, depth, and customization is far greater than what you'd expect. The main part of your deck is playing cards based on a standard 52-card deck (usually), but there's variations and modifiers that allow for over 150 possible combinations on a single card. On top of that, you have the jokers, serving as passive effects in each run. There's 150 of THOSE as well. Not to mention, the order in which you play your cards (and arrange your jokers) matters, and can mean the difference between a quick win and a rather bad loss.

That said, it's a deckbuilding Roguelike, based on poker. Luck is very obviously going to be a factor. This isn't a bad thing, but go in prepared for it.

As for graphics, well, it's meant to be like a video poker machine. You can turn the CRT effect off in the options if that's a thing you're not fond of.

Overall, for $15? This is an absolute steal. I sank about 40 hours into the Next Fest demo that had about 1/4 the content of this. The game's easily worth twice what they're charging.
This game is actually insane. Play it at all costs. I feel confident that I will play this for 100 more hours at least

Relaxing and satisfying card game. Each run you are upgrading your standard deck of 52 playing cards. Trying to make good poker hands to earn enough points. After each round you get a shop where you buy packs and cards. Mainly you are trying to get (5) Jokers that have synergy together. Jokers do all kinds of fun stuff. For example adding extra chips or multipliers to your score. This game is easy to pick up, you only need to know the poker hand combinations. Would recommend 10/10

Firstly - shoutout to michaelalfox and northernlion on twitch whose runs of this game had me hooked from months ago.

This game is wonderful. It strikes such a cool balance between BIG NUMBER DOPAMINE WE'RE GOIN CRAZY and actual strategy. You can sit and work out what will be better or you can just vibe it, and either way you'll have a great time. 

There's so much replayability here but even if there was only one or two decks in the game (there are a lot more) I found myself finally beating the starter deck and instead of thinking "sweet, onto the next one" I instead found myself wanting to run the starter deck again, but better. If that feeling translates to every deck in the game, I may never put this bad boy down.

On top of that, it's incredibly easy for the very involved and creative dev to expand should we ever get bored. Add one more deck into the game and watch everyone flock for another 3 months trying to figure it out. A handful of new jokers, or a new tarot card here and there. It is so well set up for expansion and has a dev who I think will look to improve and expand as time goes on (though I wouldn't blame them if they took a few months off!)

Hits all my endorphin reactors, makes me happy, makes me lose track of time, makes me theorycraft on public transport. All the giddy feelings I haven't had for many games over the last few years!

Endless mode is fun, but unless you know what you're doing or get insanely lucky you will get instantly crushed by ante 12 requiring a score of 300 million, which is 30x~ higher than the previous score required. There is no score jump even remotely close to this previously. If you have a deck that can actually beat ante 12, you can basically play 1 card to win any round before. If you have a pretty good but not amazing deck, it feels weird crushing everything then suddenly not coming close to winning suddenly.

[h3]Incredible game![/h3]
[b]Balatro[/b] is a roguelite card game that combines deck-building with poker mechanics. Your objective is to defeat enemy blinds by playing strategic poker hands and earning chips. To achieve this, you need to customize your deck using various card upgrades, build a deck of Jokers to enhance each hand, and create a variety of exciting [u]synergies[/u].

It's highly original and neatly designed concept! The immense diversity makes playing this game truly enjoyable. 

And all of this in a [b]magnificent audiovisual design[/b], brimming with satisfying animations and beautiful pixel art graphics.

Another plus is the the [b]immense amount of content for hours of fun[/b]. In just the free demo, I spent 10 hours, and the full version promises unimaginably more: 15 game modes, each with 8 subcategories, 150 special cards to unlock, and twice as many other items to unlock. And all of this is available on the first day of the game's release.

All of this makes this game an [u]incredibly satisfying experience[/u].

On top of that, a really [u]attractive price[/u]!

P.S. [strike]Many people don't want us to know[/strike], but the true goal of the game is buying the Wheel of Fortune [i]endlessly[/i]. 
[b]99% of Balatro players quit just before they hit something other than "Nope!" ...[/b]

If you've played poker you will easily understand this game. It hits all the right notes I want in a roguelike/lite - easy to pick up and put down, but incredibly addicting. Visuals and audio are fantastic with a non-micro transaction experience of chasing card packs and upgrades. 

Well worth the price.

Yeah this is the good stuff. Balatro is exactly what it looks like, a poker rouge like. I was worried going having the key mechanic be arcade-y, trying to achieve a score being too removed. But I'm happy to say the game is engaging.

In large part, this is due to how excellently designed the game is. It nails having a ton of different systems that all interrelate and play off each other. Passives, and cards, card modifications, jokers, and consumables. Upgrades and "builds" are varied and well balanced- shockingly so.  

Early on, I would see passive card and think, "Okay, this card is how i engage only with this mechanic." Only to find out that no, the mechanic wasn't designed around any one card and I can engage with these ideas in any way I choose. 

It's a little hard to give a final verdict yet, but this is shaping up to be my favorite rougelite since Slay the Spire. It's that good.

First, I am a complete sucker for CRT effects. So when I tried the demo back in September, I was immediately won over. Throw in my love for deckbuilders, roguelikes, and the tarot and it was a sure thing. I decided in the first hour of play that solely based on the incomplete state of the demo, this was a day one purchase for me. The 10 or so hours it took me to beat the demo, and then the Next Fest demo just solidified that decision.

I had no idea a year ago that I would rank a card game among my favorites of all time, nor did I think I would consider it nearly perfect. It's hypnotic, addictive, frustrating, and ultimately satisfying when I manage to put together devastating decks. I get something of an impression that this is the kind of poker that might be played in Twin Peaks' black lodge.

I really can't recommend it more highly. 9/10.

I was just getting into Spellrogue when Balatro dropped.  I tried a couple of poker-based deckbuilders before, and they didn't keep my attention for long.  From that previous poor experience I might have hesitated with Balatro, except for the huge rush of positive reviews pouring in thanks to their demo (which I didn't play).
I like the fact that I lost the first couple of tries - as I tend to beat the first run in most deckbuilders on first play, and I'm not really a fan of the 'make it harder for yourself without much reward for doing so' mechanic.  The third try I completed the game, which was unfortunate due to how late at night it was - although the game does have a proper save-during-run option which would normally be much appreciated.
One aspect that wasn't clear to me as I played was overlaps.  I lost a stamp when I played one on another card that had it, and then normal effects I again wasn't clear that I would lose existing effects rather than have multiple at once on a single card.  I also didn't realise that the deck won't be shuffled, hence you can't go heavy on trash mechanic which killed me on second run.  I'm not sure why this is in place, seems like we should be allowed (in the sense of shuffled deck when empty) to go heavy trash if it comes up as an option.
I love the amount of things there is to think about - jokers (and sometimes their order of sequence), tarot cards (change the cards in different ways), planets (improve multipliers of specific poker hands), spectre cards (gamble in losing a card you might like in favour of getting more rewards).  So far my initial games have been a little one-track focusing towards many of the same card leading to 5-of-a-kind hands - but that's because I didn't have jokers coming up early that would push me towards straights.
I had a calculator out on my second monitor for several hands on my winning game, working out how multiplying by 1.5 5 times from keeping certain cards in my hand, then by joker multiplier etc. will give me what score.
I also like the feature where you can see how many of different cards left in your deck to help you decide the chance of getting different cards from a discard.
Basically plays like video poker on crack with deckbuilding and roguelite elements. Addictively fun.

I am not one to leave reviews, but this game deserves it. A cheap, under 100 MB game that mixes a poker theme with a deep roguelite routine, this is the GOTY for me. Haven't had so much fun since slay the spire, but this is much less daunting, less frustrating and just pure fun.

It is not made to be fully balance, it is made to be fun, get crazy combo and just tailor your deck however you want (if you can, still those pesky RNG gods involved). Do not get me wrong - it is hard, not an easy task, it gives a proper scaling challenge. You really can't sleep on upgrading your deck and jokers, crazy hands today are gonna fall flat later.

Other than gameplay, the theme and graphics are perfect, haunted videopoker look. Art is fun and very well made, makes everything look unique. QOL is all there, I have trouble finding a fault here.

It has no right to go this hard, but it does. 

PS: Do not get turn off by the poker part - it's a poker theme more than anything, just using poker vernacular. You'll pick it up in 5 minutes of playing.

Holy smokes. This game owns.

- If you like Slay the Spire and Poker, this is the game for you.
- Lots of progression systems to keep things fresh between runs. Lots of customization options for difficulty and playstyles.
- Music is very chill and laid back
- Tarot cards, cart and planet cards are fun. It feels like you are playing an RPG while also playing poker.

Even if you've been burned out on the many other deckbuilding roguelites that have followed in the wake of Slay the Spire -- don't skip this one. 

This is one of the really, really good ones. 

The mechanics of getting to your deck to shine all feel very balanced and satisfying to achieve. Menus are clean and snappy. Tooltips are informative and mostly self-explanatory. The pixel art is quality and goes well with the CRT filter, although everything (I mean everything) on the screen shifting around feels like taking an ambien. The soundtrack wraps things together in a strange, satisfying, and hypnotic (as advertised!) complete package.

The cherry on top is that it's also very cheap.

Highly recommended.

There's potential for something great here, and I was having a lot of fun for about half the time, but the boss RNG killed 2 of my 3 runs by debuffing my exact build, and only having 2 rounds advance notice is not enough time to pivot.  Having to depend on not rolling bosses that perfectly counter you to win a run left a sour taste in my mouth, so I refunded. 

Variance in offered joker cards/tarots that can make a deck more or less powerful is okay. Variance in the form of "you either instantly lose or you don't" is not. Imagine how much worse Slay the Spire would be if it had a boss that said "your attacks no longer work."

I think the best fix would be reworking Debuff from "gain 0 chips" to something like "gain 1/2 chips"

I'll purchase again if this gets reworked.

Pretty good rougelite deckbuilding poker game. Lots of creative ways to build your deck, with the main goal being to beat increasingly difficult scores and conditions. Pretty high replayability and it's fun finding combos and getting all the secret unlocks. Highly suggest trying the demo or watching a short playthrough to get an idea; you do not really need to know how to play poker to enjoy this.

My personal gripes:
It is lacking in atmospheric depth, just video poker with no lore, characters, motivation surrounding it. You're not even playing against a player or enemy, just a score. So it does feel like playing solitaire in a way.

The game doesn't have consistent problem-solving card text so effects can be very unclear. For example some cards give you "+1 hand", but some cards say "+1 hand per round" which is functionally the same, but because its described differently its easy to assume it does something else like maybe its a temporary effect or that the effect is reapplied every round instead of one time permanently. Some cards have unnecessarily long text that make it more confusing than it is, such as "all cards you play gain +10 multi if they score", obviously if a card scored then it was played, and there's no need to specify "all cards" because there's no exceptions or conditions. So it couldve just read "scored cards gain +10 multi".

Completing the ascension system requires you to beat the game with every deck with every difficulty. This feels excessively grindy having to go through all the easier ascensions with every deck multiple times just to reach the more difficult fun stuff. There is an "unlock everything" button in the options menu to skip it, but this also skips all the unlockable cards and secrets. It would be nice if this grind is reduced to beating each difficulty with any deck, and/or there is a separate unlock all button just for the ascensions.
ALL HAIL OLBAP

In ancient Rome, a balatro was a professional jester or buffoon. Balatrones were paid for their jests, and the tables of the wealthy were generally open to them for the sake of the amusement they afforded. There are various theories about the origin of the term. In Horace, Balatro is used as a proper name: Servilius Balatro. An old scholiast derives the common word balatro from the proper name, suggesting that buffoons were called balatrones because Servilius Balatro was a buffoon, though others have since objected to this account. Festus derives the word from blatea, and supposes buffoons to have been called balatrones because they were dirty fellows, covered with spots of mud from walking. Another writer suggests a derivation from barathrum, because they, so to speak, carried their jesting to market, even into the very depth of the shambles Balatro may be connected with balare, "to bleat like a sheep", and hence, to speak sillily. 

-Source: Wikipedia

It also doesn't drag its feet when getting you into the action - within just a round or two you already feel like you're making progress in a run. There's no early game slog whatsoever. I love rouge-like games and I haven't been as sucked into one as I am with Balatro in a long long time. It's a game of the highest quality. I can already tell there are dozens if not hundreds of hours of replayability packed inside of this one. If you like deckbuilders, roguelikes or strategy games definitely pick this up.

I've been following this game since the first demo dropped and as a lover of Poker, this has given me the fun stimulation I crave. 

Pros: Huge array of beautiful illustrated jokers, plenty of content for only 15 bucks, replayability is near infinite based on how you like to play, collection system is packed with challenges and nudges you to try different playing styles.

Cons: Honestly can't think of any right now but as I play I will update this post.

In summary, this game is big and cheap. I would have been fine paying 20 or 25 for this especially after seeing how fast the devs worked on initial feedback while also being inclusive with their players. I hope to maybe see DLC in the future.

Wow! This is an amazing game. I play a lot of "Deckbuilder" style games on Steam and I absolutely love this fresh and innovative take on the genre. 

The game starts out very simple, look at your hand of eight cards, discard and redraw the cards you can't use, and then make the best possible poker hand to score points. If you can achieve a certain of threshold of total points across three hands of poker, then you win the match. Then Layered on top of this simple and enjoyable core, Balatro builds an engaging deckbuilding experience. 

In one run perhaps you transform some black cards into Hearts, add an extra Ace of Hearts to your deck, then "level up" the amount of points you get from a Flush ... Continue down this path and end up with a deck that contains a crazy number of Hearts and generates crazy combos with Flush after Flush. 

Then on the next run, you are offered a Joker that provides the passive effect: "Your Odd cards score more points" ... So you destroy some of your even cards, and transform other even cards into 7's and 9's, and then you buy a couple more 9's for good measure ...  finally you Re-Roll the between match shop until you find the Joker with the passive effect that adds additional points to any hand that contains 3-of-a-Kind (Full-House, 3-of-a-Kind, 4-of-a-Kind, 5-of-a-Kind) ... and score crazy points with Full Houses of 7's over 9's

Continue on and unlock more decks with different starting bonuses to provide more variation in your runs and increase replayabilty. As you become more skilled at making clever choices to enhance your deck, you can challenge harder and harder difficulties. This game comes with a crazy amount of content and countless strategic options. I look forward to playing this game for a long time. 

If you like "Deckbuilder" games ... or if you just like Poker ... give this game a try. I am confident you will not be disappointed.

I put more hours into the demo of this game than to many, many games in my library that I paid money for. In fact, I was worried that I'd be bored of the game and the full release wouldn't be enough content beyond the demo. I was wrong. The full release is absolutely amazing.

The gameplay is, of course, very satisfying.

But on top of that the dynamic music, curated pixel art, and smooth physics are phenomenal. Mind you, none of these things are even remotely needed for a game that would functionally play the same if it was in the old Windows XP solitaire format.

Get it, and let the CRT fuzz and chacha-synthwave wash over you.
Let a parade of psychedelic jokers and ludicrous dollar amounts dance around you.
Let your inner poker-cheat run rampant, creating all the flush-houses and fives-of-a-kind its little heart desires.

I'm a longtime TCG/CCG/Card Battler player, on top of any number of basic playing card games. Something about card games just works for me.

Balatro scratches nearly every card game itch. 
The rogue-like elements aren't super punishing, nor is the gameplay too repetitive (unless you're just not into games involving poker hands in which case this really isn't the game for you).
Each run pushes you to make a series of choices. Some choices are about weighing short term vs. long term benefits. Some choices are about committing to a specific style or path of progression without necessarily knowing if you'll be able to back it up. Some choices are a simple question of mathematics.

I played two different demo versions of this game before purchasing. This was one of the most confident purchases I've ever made on steam. If you enjoy virtual card games of nearly any kind, you'll probably dig Balatro.

I'll start with the negative: Not a fan of the "video poker on a CRT screen" aesthetic. That's it, that's my only real complaint with the game.

Roguelike deckbuilding poker might not sound all that good, but they knocked it out of the park with this one. Jokers change the rules in strange ways, and there are always combos to be made and interesting choices to go through with them. 

Do I power up a straight flush that I'll probably never get, or pour everything into making my seven aces even better? Do I use the cards I've been dealt, or discard in the hopes of getting even better? What about my joker that loses power every time I discard, is it still worth it? Do I fight the little blind, or take the free bonus instead?

Look it's undeniable that a large part of the appeal of this game is watching the numbers go up. If pushing your luck and tasting the sweet sweet highs and the utterly BS totally not my fault for risking it lows isn't appealing then there are other games with more depth.

None of that is to say that this game is shallow though! There's a large helping of chance, yes, but if you push that generous serve to the side underneath you'll find a game with a reasonable degree of strategy and tactics. Some cards will require you to structure your entire run around being able to tactically play the right hand at the right time, others will encouraging engineering your deck in order to become a lean mean consistency producing machine, others will let you abandon care and dig through piles of cards in order to assemble the optimal hand.

complicating this are "boss blinds" which throw a spanner into the works by placing restrictions on what you're allowed to use in the fight up to them. You'll have at minimum 2 rounds to prepare but if you're going for a highly focused build there are *usually* opportunities to pick up something to mitigate bad boss luck before they show up (with the associated opportunity cost of buying something you may not need).

It's also worth mentioning that's it's presented beautifully, with comfortable and stylish visual and sound design.

Very rare is the game where it feels like every other run you think "This is PEAK" only to see new unlocks or start a new run and realize you weren't even at the base of the peak, you were in a TRENCH compared to this run. 

Visuals are crisp and has a SPEED SLIDER FROM 0.5-4X (OTHER DEVS TAKE NOTES PLEASE!) 
The backing music is nice although limited in variety but given the size/price thats not unreasonable. 
Price point of the game itself is more than worth it for the content received (note, have alot of hours in the demo plan to play plenty more in this) 
That said, this is a POKER-ROGUELIKE aka Double-Nested RNG. If you are someone who likes roguelikes where your runs eventually become consistent this is not the game for you I would be genuinely baffled if this game ever sees something like TBOIs 500+ winstreaks. This game is not about winstreaking its about high peaks and embittering lows. 

So, basically, get out there and drive the casino out of business or get folded like a shirt.

Addicting, mesmerizing poker roguelike.

Has a more straightforward progression system compared to other roguelikes... most of the stuff you unlock is just from playing, altough there are some with requirements as well.

Yes you need some poker knowledge here but only to know the hands. The game actually tells you if the cards you selected make a specific hand or not.

Worth the $15 for sure. There's a LOT of mileage here.

As for the cons, some cards have a bit of confusing text; if you loose a run it comes as a kind of shock; there's an annoying CRT effect that is OPTIONAL but I think some people won't realize that; the boss battles I think could have been a bit more creative but they're fine; it's way more reliant on luck compared to other roguelikes.

Other: 21:9 support; game speed option; game has a lot of other languages but are still in beta (as of this moment); achievements and steam cloud;

Most likely my favourite roguelike.
Put 100 hours into the demo before the game even released in full, so I would already be satisfied if the game was mostly in the same state, but there's so much more to discover now. The game has a habit of making you feel like you're the smartest/luckiest person in the world whenever you get a proper build going, and there's plenty of tools to make just about any build you can think of work. Immensely satisfying. 
The soundtrack - despite being essentially a single track - is perfect and fits the overall theme like a glove. For that matter, [i]everything[/i] about the presentation just feels perfect.
There is less meta-progression in this game than in some other roguelikes - mostly just new jokers, decks, and vouchers that you can find in future runs. Personally, I find this more rewarding for this game, but to some this could feel too rng heavy. I think this fits the poker aesthetic well though - we be gamblin'

Already dumped 15+ hours into the demo alone. Was frothing at the mouth for the full release. Just 3 hours into the full game, so much extra content, I know this is going to quickly become a classic. An incredible formula that'll have you going "just one more Blind..." for 8 hours straight, lmao.

You know that moment in Slay the Spire or your other favourite roguelike where you manage to find the exact right combination of items where everything just goes exponential and hoses down the boss in about three seconds? Yeah that's this game. Make all of your cards Diamonds and every hand you play a straight flush, and pick up items that give you exponential points every time you play a Diamond, a flush, a straight, or a straight flush, and let it all combine and gel together until That Number Gets Bigger, Baybeee.

Don't let my hours at time of review fool you, I put 10x those numbers into each of the demos and it would have been even more if the full game didn't release.

There is something extremely heartwarming hearing people refer to balatro as their favorite game before the full game even releases, and I can only imagine those people are absolutely pogged out of their gourd at the full release, as I certainly am.

There is an unbelievable amount of depth here: the synergies are wildly satisfying. the unlocks are free dopamine, and the wins are exhilarating. $15 is a legitimate STEAL for a game of this caliber and i will be purchasing it on switch even if i never play it just to support localthunk a tiny bit more.

While I do believe there are some bosses that leave a lot to be desired, I played quite a bit of the demo of this game and have been excited for it for almost a year now. This game is easily worth $15 if you'd be interested in similar casino-roguelike games such as Luck Be a Landlord. I believe Balatro offers a very novel gameplay loop, winning strategies are rather copious, and for the most part it doesn't really feel like it cheats me, bar the one or two bosses that in my opinion fundamentally break how the game is played (I'm looking at you, upside down hands).

Highly, highly recommend.

A must have in your library if you like a good deckbuilding roguelike. The visuals are unique, the gameplay is insanely fun and the options and decisions you are presented with during your runs are numerous. 

You won't get bored easily and there is so much to explore and learn. I've spent a good chunk of time in the demo and will sink a lot of hours in the full version. 

The developer listens to what the players have to say about in-game balance and works tirelessly to ensure the best experience possible. Truly a labor of love. 

Also have a unique upside of scratching that gambler's itch without actually going broke at the poker table in some shady casino, so it's easy to say: never stop gambling, the big win is just around the corner.

I was only expecting some new jokers to be added at full release after the wonderful demo and I am actually shocked at the scope of this game. There's so many different decks to play as, challenges to do, so many different ways to play... It's one of the best card roguelikes I've played since probably Monster Train.

A roguelike deck builder with poker elements, it definitely has some challenging RNG. Some runs seem to be almost destined to fail, but it is fun to see if a run can be salvaged. So far, it seems to have enough content and replay value for the price.

This is the most I have anticipated a game release possibly ever - the demo was phenomenal and the full release has lived up to the hype and more! 

Im a big fan of deck-builders and rogue-lites, and Balatro perfectly hits the balance of deceptively simple gameplay with plenty of strategic depth and crunchy math just below the surface. The different combinations of decks, jokers, and packs make every run unique. Runs are short enough that its easy to try out new strategies and combinations on your next try (although there is an option to continue on in Endless Mode after any successful run!). Its never too frustrating when the RNG just doesnt pan out - you just get more ideas for the next attempt. 

Ive been playing primarily on Steam deck, and the controls are smooth and it runs great! The developer has also been active in the games Discord throughout the demo working on balance changes and patching bugs. 

11/10 would recommend to fans of Slay the Spire, Monster Train, Wildfrost, etc. - for me, its already easily up there with Slay the Spire and my top game of the year so far (and I expect it may very well end up as my #1 game of 2024!)

REALLY good, pretty dang addicting, though I am struggling a bit never having played poker before and having to constantly remind myself what a straight or a flush is. I ain't great at this game, but its fun as hell.

As far as i can tell it keeps things simple, no real lore or story or nothing that ive seen yet, which is fine, its just cards. play the cards. 

One thing id like to see: a way to customize cosmetic aspects like the card backs/backgrounds/idk sound effects, just for funsies. Could be either mod support or just in game. I know the "decks" function as run selectors, but could still have cosmetic decks on top of that! and could just have like, different patterns for the bgs, like lil waves or sparkley stuff, but it still doing all the color changing for the effects and stuff. 

of course thats ya kno. less important than the actual gameplay, but customizable cardbacks are always fun in games like this.

I am 35 years old.

My ex-husband and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5  minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak girl I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the father of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The man I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The cards, oh how they beckon to me in the dead of night, their siren song echoing through the desolate corridors of my shattered mind. I cannot escape their haunting melody, and with each passing moment, my grip on the mundane reality of my forsaken life slips further into the abyss.

As the moon casts its feeble light upon the forsaken room where I huddle in solitary communion with your eldritch deck, I find myself ensnared in a web of obsession that defies reason. The very essence of the cards permeates my every waking hour, and I am consumed by a hunger that transcends the need for sustenance. I cannot eat; the taste of earthly fare pales in comparison to the intoxicating allure of those spectral cards.

My wife, in her pitiable state, beseeches me to attend to the needs of our offspring; to partake in the rituals of familial duty. Yet, her pleas fall upon deaf ears, for there is nothing but The Deck. The cries of our children go unheeded as I succumb to the irresistible pull of the malevolent game. The world outside has become a mere illusion, a fleeting mirage that fades into insignificance before the eternal allure, that whisper heard in the darkest corners of my mind. "Just one more draw."

Sleep, once a sanctuary of respite, has abandoned me entirely. The insidious whispers invade my dreams, intertwining with the very fabric of my subconscious. I am haunted by visions of arcane symbols and grotesque imagery, a phantasmagoria that mirrors the twisted reality of my waking hours. The bed, once a haven of repose, has transformed into a cursed altar where I lay my weary body to be tormented by the ceaseless yearning for that profane ritual, known only by the name... Balatro.

I saw Northernlion at a grocery store in Vancouver the other day.

I told him how cool it was to meet him in person, but I didnt want to be a douche and bother him and ask him for photos or anything. He said, Oh, like youre doing now? I was taken aback, and all I could say was Huh? but he kept cutting me off and going huh? huh? huh? and closing his hand shut in front of my face. I walked away and continued with my shopping, and I heard him chuckle as I walked off. When I came to pay for my stuff up front I saw him trying to walk out the doors with like fifteen Milky Ways in his hands without paying. The girl at the counter was very nice about it and professional, and was like Sir, you need to pay for those first. At first he kept pretending to be tired and not hear her, but eventually turned back around and brought them to the counter. When she took one of the bars and started scanning it multiple times, he stopped her and told her to scan them each individually to prevent any electrical infetterence, and then turned around and winked at me. I dont even think thats a word. After she scanned each bar and put them in a bag and started to say the price, he kept interrupting her by yawning really loudly.

[h2] Poker + Roguelike = Addiction [/h2]

Why is Balatro so good?

-Amazing amount of content for the pricepoint and almost infinite replayability if you enjoy poker

-For people not too knowledgeable about poker, it's still easy to pick up and play, given the game gives you information on all possible scoring hands in a digestible way within a single button press

-Roguelike format works very well with the poker, making it in some cases basically a House Rules style game, with a dash of cheating (making your whole hand a single rank, etc.)

-Still has potential to grow and I am excited to continue playing and awaiting any possible additions to the winning formula

Don't let the hours played fool you. I've been playing the occasional demo for balatro as much as the dev let me, more or less running up at least 60 hours between them. 

Balatro is a game where you play poker hands to beat a dealer's score (the Blind). You're allowed a number of discards - tossing up to five cards to get an equal number back - and hands to play to add up to this score. 
Score is totaled by starting with a base score for the hand, then adding the value of the cards played in the hand, then multiplying by the base multiplier for the hand. So, two jacks, two queens, all different suits? that's a two pair, which is worth 20 points with a x2 multiplier, and each face card is forty. So you get 120 points for that. Not the worst hand, but near the bottom. 

Once you beat the initial blind, you get money based on your performance to spend in the shop, which is where Balatro explodes in complexity. Here you can buy tarot cards (which modify your cards, by converting suits or destroy cards outright, for example), Planet cards, which upgrade hand base scores, and Jokers. Jokers are, more or less, equipment: You can have up to five at a time, and they do things like simply adding multiplier, making specific cards add more points, or weird things like "if you discard a single card first, destroy it and get 3 dollars". 

As your run progresses, you're expected to gather jokers and modify your deck towards a strategy of one form or another. Maybe you find a Joker that re-triggers played lower cards, a joker that causes fibonacchi numbers to add multiplier, and now you're tearing into each shop hoping to add smaller number cards to your deck, eliminating face cards with a vendetta, and hunting for Jokers that can allow you to play hands of nothing but fibonacchi numbers. 

Because you *will* need to enhance your deck. The blinds escalate, ratcheting up and up each one you defeat. And every three blinds is a Boss. 
Bosses are powerful blinds that come with additional rules. Some are benign as reducing your hand size - others will torment you with things like "only one hand type for this blind" or taking money for each card played. Preparing for bosses, whether by making your deck simply strong enough to bull through, or by subverting their rules, is part of Balatro's core. 

The feel of the game is unique among deckbuilding roguelikes. It presents a CRT, retro-esque aesthetic of ancient poker machines. The music is reminiscent of Risk of Rain. Perhaps its most daring move is to only have a SINGLE NPC in the entire game, the tutorial agent who teaches you the game and pops up at the end of each run - win or lose - to either mock or congratulate you. There's no enemies to really speak of. The bosses, even, are vague, conceptual - "The Wall", "The mouth". There's a sense of comedy and jest throughout - joker art can be anything from The Hack - a poor standup comedian giving a terrible set - or Mystic Summit, a pile of floating rocks reaching into the sky. 

The downsides of the game are few, if any. The game wears its luck-based nature on its sleeve, but as the game proceeds, it can grow more and more 'rocket-tag'y, with hands swinging harder and harder against higher and higher stakes, and so by mid or late game not getting the right hand even after several discards and hard work customizing the deck can feel pretty bad. Not getting the tools you're looking for also has an element of luck, and sometimes, a deck just isn't gonna make it - But this feeling is mitigated by the casino-esque feel of the whole game, in my opinion, as if the game is looking you dead in the eyes as it deals you a trash hand or forces terrible, cruel boss blinds on you. 

Balatro is one of my favorite games this year. It has a lot of staying power, the price is really affordable, and it's as strong as other classics in its genre. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

Balatro is better and far more complex than Monster Train, ironically with the well-worn template of poker. It on par with Slay the Spire in terms of the gameplay loop construction and as crisp as Inscryption's short runs. The art of a feel-good roguelike deck builder is how much of its emergent gameplay *feels* like cheating. Somehow the base being poker gives it a solid base for iteration, automatically becoming even easier than its peers to pick up, but equally difficult to master.

The demo already offered a lot of ideas and the full release just cranked it up to an 11. All of this complexity packed in a very visually pleasing game with no glaring bugs or issues on release date should be a standard for every single rougelike deckbuilder that is to come after Balatro. For this price this is an absolute STEAL.

Very fun game and a fresh version of the Roguelite genre, BUT...

Just like the myriad other card games in this genre, you will have a VERY significant amount of runs that end in disappointment.  Unlike the action roguelite games that allow your skill to overcome a bad seed, this game will just force you to quit and start over because you happened to get 2 bad hand draws in a row.  Super fun, but there is absolutely room for improvement. 

Tip: If you don't get at least a Queen high straight, Face card flush, or Full House on Round 1, just start over.  No point in missing out on the bonus $1.

Balatro caught my eye as the #3 most played game in 2024's Steam Next Fest. The hype is warranted. Balatro is a one-developer labor of love and, like many of its kind, Balatro oozes of personal style: hypnotic, mysterious, and cheeky, the game feels like a wild dream in all of its art, sound design, and visual effects. 

On top of its unforgettable theming and charm, playing Balatro feels truly liberating: unlike in other roguelikes where you hope to fall into an existing build archetype, Balatro allows you to create your own synergies with its Joker system. Add onto its 150 jokers the 15 different decks, dozens of deck-modifying Tarot and Planet cards, and rare Foil/Holographic/Polychrome card versions, and no run can ever feel stale.

This is an instant titan of the genre and a must-buy for roguelike players.

I taught my son to play poker a few months back, and he returned the favor by pointing me to the demo version of Balatro.  It has quickly become my game of choice.  Poker, but with more ridiculous hands, decks, and modifiers.  What's that?  A straight flush made up of A 3 5 8 of spades and 6 of diamonds, because of the wacky jokers that make it possible to score a 4-card flush, a 4-card straight, and have spaces in straights?  Yeah, it's kinda like that.  Excellent game, and it's got an extraordinary amount of content.

Balatro is a highly original and neatly designed concept combining Poker and deckbuilding in a roguelike format. The aim is to play poker hands from your deck to ultimately defeat the blinds and move to the next round.

The twist with the gameplay is the ability to collect power-ups and purchase other elements along the way which can boost your score through multi's and combo's as you progress. Some rounds can also have negative aspects so you have to be quite strategic in what to play and when. 

This will definitely prove to be a very addictive and challenging game and it's really good to see a poker game emerge from the usual fantasy titles we see in this genre. Really attractive price too!

Balatro is a game about clowning on the rules of poker and substituting them with your own, much stupider ones.

"High card is the worst hand in poker"? Nope, I beelined into high card upgrades so now a single 2 of Spades gives me a thousand times more points than a royal flush.

"A straight is five cards in sequence"? Nope, I changed the rules and now Ace, 3, 4, and 6 is a valid straight. Also, my fifth card is just a rock.

"There are only four aces in a deck of cards"? Then how did I play five of a kind just now, and why does my deck have 17 more aces in it?

These are just a few of the situations you'll run into in Balatro. It's been a long time since I've played a game that so thoroughly prides itself on being broken to pieces by its playerbase, and I'm loving every minute of it.

Played demo for a few hours... I have never waited for the release date of any game like for this one. (besides Cyberpunk 2077 :P ) 
Do you enjoy deckbuilders and games where you can scale gained points so much that they punch a hole through your roof top? You NEED to check this out. 
This game is simple, yet innovative but also includes many different mechanics which are ingenious. 
1. You get standard playing deck, what feels familiar to anyone who played card games.
2. You create standard poker like hands, which give you more points.
3. Reach the goal in a few hands, or game over.

Simple? Yes. Addictive? Yes.

Mechanics:
- During your run you can buy jokers which give you extra abilities, extra cash, multipliers of your scores - more points
- You can get Planet cards which permanently for this run upgrade types of hands - MORE POINTS
- You can upgrade specific cards from your deck which will add multiplications - EVEN. MORE. POINTS.
- All of these upgrades can be bought in the Shop for money which you earn after defeating blinds (reaching a goal)
- Shops have a huuuuge variety of items, each run is different 
- You can unlock different decks which have cool starting abilities.
- You can unlock difficulty level...
and many, many more... 

If you really want to compare this deckbuilder (kinda roguelike) to Slay the Spire:
- You don't explicitly choose a path here, but you are allowed to skip minor "enemies" to get some bonus. 
- Unlike in Slay the Spire, all card upgrades are permanent (for the run) even if done during "a fight". Slay the Spire card upgrades are permanent either if it says so, or if done outside of a battle. 
- Combos here really DO SCALE. But you need to experience it on your own.
There are a lot of other differences, but I just don't want to bore you. 

There is even such an attention to detail how cards glare, have cool effects. Or when you open packs it just feels so right. 
Fans of collectibles will for sure enjoy this one. 

Depth? 10/10
Graphics? 9/10
Music? 9/10
"One. More. Turn." Syndrome? YES.
Quality to price ratio: INSTA BUY.

Until now (a few hours in demo and almost an hours in the base game) I didn't find any bugs. What only shows how the game is polished or that I didn't understand how the game is summing the points and how it should do it (might have overheated my brain after some of the calculations)

If you are still reading...

i spent WEEKS playing the demo.

the least i could do in exchange is buy the game.

you don't need "good graphics" or an "enthralling story" like AAA games as a service would have you believe.

what you need is fun gameplay and systems that flesh out that gameplay to it's fullest. Balatro is a Deckbuilding Poker Roguelike that takes every idea in those three words (without any of the downsides of gambling addictions) and masterfully shuffles them together into something fresh and fun, and most importantly of all, it WANTS you to break it. it WANTS you to become OP. it WANTS you to put every piece of the game together to turn your starting decks into billion-chip scoring hands that make the game start fast forwarding out of a mix of spite and glee for how bustedly OP you are.

that is why you should buy Balatro after trying the demo. once it sinks it's hooks in you, you will realize how much of a weirdly fair yet fun and hard Roguelike Balatro is. and fuck me i am going to keep coming back for more.

Overall Balatro review:
10/10 masterpiece that you absolutely must own if you are a fan of rogue-likes or card games.
No other game had me putting in nearly 30 hours on their demo. 

The concept is so simple yet so smart at the same time.
You can easily know what youre doing within a few minutes and yet still get stuck strategizing because thats just how much depth is actually in this game.

You have planets that enhance your hand types
You have jokers that change your entire build
You have tarot cards for deck manipulation
And you have spectral cards that create these monkey's paw situations.
All combined, bring a fresh take on the traditional poker card game that brings an immense amount of replayablility. 
I can genuinely see this being my main rogue-like of choice for many many years.
For $15, its hard to beat
I've spent more time on the demo for this game than most fully released AAA games in the last month

Really, really fun poker roguelite that has you playing hands to earn chips and "mult" (score multipliers) based on the type of hand (ie 2 of a kind, flush, etc) you play. With the addition of Jokers (run modifiers that alter how cards are scored), tarot and planet cards, the possibilities are endless. 

Plays amazingly on the steam deck and/or with a controller at your PC. Highly recommend this one if you are a fan of the genre and a truly new and unique twist. Really looking forward to seeing how this evolves, what else is added, and if workshop functionality ever comes this will be one played for years and years with the likes of Binding of Isaac.
